sect1.title: 28 Coryneform Gram-Positive Rods*

para.phrase: ANA LUÍZA MATTOS-GUARALDI, LOUISY SANCHES DOS SANTOS, AND VERÔNICA VIANA VIEIRA

sect1.para: Coryneform bacteria comprising aerobically or facultatively anaerobically growing, asporogenous, non-acid-fast Gram-positive rods with irregular morphology are presented in this chapter. TrueCorynebacterium species exhibit typical club-shaped morphologies, whereas all the other taxa discussed in this chapter show an irregular morphology. Corynebacterium spp. form the predominant group and include diphtheria toxin (DT)-producing Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the causative agent of classic diphtheria, which was once a major cause of illness and death among children (1). Diphtheria was first described in the 5th century BC by Hippocrates and “coryne” means “club” in ancient Greek.

During the past 3 decades, more than 135Corynebacterium spp. have been recognized. Geographical variations in the frequency of Corynebacterium spp. as pathogens of different types of infections have been reported (2). There have been a number of studies demonstrating the relevance of DT-producing and non-DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. as etiologic agents not only of classic and zoonotic diphtheria, but also of a range of types of community-acquired and health care-associated infections and/or outbreaks worldwide. Hospital-acquired infections are responsible for high mortality rates, longer length of stay, and increased hospital costs, and therefore are an increasing cause for concern in health care worldwide. Clinical implications of multidrug-resistant (MDR) strains and expression of virulence mechanisms have been increasingly investigated for various Corynebacterium and other coryneform species. Despite our improved understanding of the clinical significance of these organisms, pathogenic Corynebacterium and coryneform species isolated from infected patients are sometimes still considered contaminants. Their presence is often neglected by clinicians and laboratory professionals, mainly due to the difficulty in identification of clinical isolates and distinguishing between colonization and infection. Moreover, antimicrobial susceptibility testing for Corynebacterium spp. and other coryneform pathogens is not performed in many laboratories (3).

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: Coryneform bacteria, except for theExiguobacterium genus, belong in the Actinomycetota phylum, formerly known as Actinobacteria (1, 4), and have a high G+C content spanning approximately 50% to over 70%. The Actinobacteria class, first included in the International Code of Nomenclature of Prokaryotes (5), is considered an illegitimate name, with orphaned orders (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/class/actinobacteria, 2022). Studies based on genomic analyses have led to proposed classes and orders of the Actinomycetota phylum, which include only species with available genome sequences. Therefore, phylogenetic ranks (i.e., classes and orders) remain unclear due to species whose genome sequences are not available. Phylogenetic investigations using 16S rRNA gene sequencing and, increasingly, analyses by whole-genome sequencing have frequently confirmed the framework established by traditional chemotaxonomic descriptions of families and genera, including corynebacteria (6, 7). Taxonomic changes were proposed to reclassify or create novel families, genera, and species. These are presented in Table 1, along with clinical features for the more common species recovered from human infection. Only effectively described and validly named genera and species were considered, with a focus on taxa that are clinically relevant. The List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature (LPSN) was used as the primary, but not exclusive, reference (https://www.bacterio.net/).

sect1.title: Family Brevibacteriaceae
sect1.para: TheBrevibacteriaceae family comprises genera Brevibacterium, Sediminivirga, and Spelaeicoccus (1), with only Brevibacterium spp. having been isolated from human infections.

sect1.title: Genus Brevibacterium
sect1.para: Brevibacterium spp. are Gram-positive, aerobic, non-spore-forming cocci or short rod-shaped bacterial cells. The genus Brevibacterium is currently represented by 36 validly published species (as of August 2022) isolated from different sources, such as dairy products and other habitats. Nine species of the genus Brevibacterium have been isolated from human infections: Brevibacterium casei, Brevibacterium epidermidis, Brevibacterium iodinum, Brevibacterium luteolum, Brevibacterium mcbrellneri, Brevibacterium otitidis, Brevibacterium paucivorans, Brevibacterium ravenspurgense (B. massiliense, heterotypic synonym), and Brevibacterium sanguinis (8, 9).

sect1.title: Family Cellulomonadaceae
sect1.para: TheCellulomonadaceae family was amended according to genome-based taxonomic analyses. Five genera of the family were removed and only the genera Actinotalea, Cellulomonas, and Pseudactinotalea remain in the family (6).

sect1.title: Genus Cellulomonas
sect1.para: Cellulomonas spp. are Gram-positive pleomorphic bacilli, aerobic, motile, asporogenous, and with typically anaerobic growth in static cultures. Most strains are cellulolytic. There are 31 validly published species in the genus Cellulomonas, of which only Cellulomonas hominis and Cellulomonas denverensis have been reported as etiologic agents of human infections (10–12).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Dermabacter
sect2.para: Dermabacter spp. are facultative anaerobes, nonmotile, short rods, that are catalase positive and oxidase negative. The genus Dermabacter contains three validly described species, including Dermabacter jinjuensis and Dermabacter vaginalis, which have been isolated from human clinical specimens. The third species, D. hominis, is a member of the human skin microbiota and is a human pathogen (13, 14).

sect2.title: ■ Genera Brachybacterium and Helcobacillus
sect2.para: The genusBrachybacterium includes facultative anaerobic or aerobic, nonmotile and non-spore-forming bacterial cells that vary in shape from coccoid forms (stationary phase) to rods (exponential phase) (15). Brachybacterium spp. can be isolated from varied sources, including food products. Although the genus Brachybacterium contains 24 validly published species, reported human infections are rare. Four cases were recently described, including cases of bacteremia and endophthalmitis following surgery (16–18).

The genusHelcobacillus includes only Helcobacillus massiliensis, which is an aerobic, nonmotile, non-spore-forming, Gram-positive bacterium which forms short/irregular or straight rods. The type strain was isolated from a human cutaneous discharge (19).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Janibacter
sect2.para: The genusJanibacter currently includes nine species, of which four have been increasingly described in cases of human infections of normally sterile sites: Janibacter hoylei, Janibacter indicus, Janibacter melanis, and Janibacter terrae. Janibacter are nonmotile, non-spore-forming, and with Gram-variable or Gram-positive coccoidal to rod forms in singles, pairs, or irregular clumps; not acid fast, aerobic, and chemoorganotrophic (20–22).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Agromyces
sect2.para: The genusAgromyces includes 40 species which are mainly found in soil, plant rhizosphere, and/or aquatic sources. Only two cases of human infections, both due to Agromyces mediolanus, were reported. In both cases, the clinical isolates were identified by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) (23, 24). A. mediolanus bacterial cells are nonmotile, thin, and have short branching filaments or irregular rods, with coccoidal forms being observed with age.

sect2.title: ■ Genus Canibacter
sect2.para: TheCanibacter genus includes only one species, Canibacter oris. C. oris is facultatively anaerobic, catalase and oxidase negative, and nonmotile. The cells are Gram-positive bacilli that may be arranged in V and Y shapes; coccoid forms are frequently observed (25). C. oris was recovered from two cases of human wound infections caused by dog bites (25, 26). Human infections due to C. oris may occur more frequently than already described in the literature, as in many dog bite wound infections, no microbiological examination is ordered. In addition, dog bite wound infection is usually due to polymicrobial agents that may overgrow microaerophilic C. oris.

sect2.title: ■ Genus Curtobacterium
sect2.para: The genusCurtobacterium occurs in natural environments including plants and soil, and it also includes pathogenic bacteria of plants, including agricultural crops. There are eight validly described species in the Curtobacterium genus, although additional taxonomic analyses are required (27).

Curtobacteria are motile, oxidative, and Gram-positive filamentous rods. These bacteria are infrequently isolated from human infections.Curtobacterium spp. were recovered from sputum of patients with respiratory illness and catheter-associated infection (28). There are single case reports of Curtobacterium as the cause of a brain abscess and septic arthritis following injury by a thorn (29, 30).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Leifsonia
sect2.para: The genusLeifsonia consists of 12 validly described species isolated from aquatic and terrestrial environments. Leifsonia aquatica, previously classified as “Corynebacterium aquaticum,” is associated with freshwater (31). Leifsonia spp. have been infrequently recognized as causative agents of human infections, with L. aquatica identified in most reported cases. L. aquatica causes peritonitis in patients on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis, bacteremia in hemodialysis patients, and bacteremia in immunocompromised hosts (32, 33).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Microbacterium
sect2.para: TheMicrobacterium genus contains 129 validly described species recovered from different environments. Members of this genus are motile by lateral flagella or nonmotile, and obligately aerobic. They are Gram-positive short rods. In older cultures, they form shorter or spherical elements, but a marked rod-coccus cycle is not observed (34).

SomeMicrobacterium spp. have been increasingly reported as human pathogens. The species most frequently isolated from clinical specimens are Microbacterium oxydans, Microbacterium paraoxydans, Microbacterium foliorum, and Microbacterium laevaniformans. Microbacterium spp. that have been found to cause human infections include Microbacterium arborescens, Microbacterium barkeri, Microbacterium binotii, Microbacterium esteraromaticum, M. foliorum, Microbacterium hydrocarbonoxydans, Microbacterium hominis, Microbacterium oleivorans, Microbacterium phyllosphaerae, Microbacterium resistens, Microbacterium thalassium, and Microbacterium yannicii, among others (3, 35, 36). Cases of endophthalmitis, catheter-related bloodstream infections, and peritoneal dialysis- and orthopedic implant-associated infections due to Microbacterium spp. have been reported (36).

sect2.title: ■ Genera Pseudoclavibacter and Gulosibacter
sect2.para: The generaPseudoclavibacter and Gulosibacter were described in 2004 (37). The genus Pseudoclavibacter was proposed to reclassify the Brevibacterium helvolum DSM 20419Tstrain as Pseudoclavibacter helvolus. According to taxonomic studies of Zimmermannella species, Zimmermannella bifida and Zimmermannella faecalis were transferred to the genus Gulosibacter (6). To date, Pseudoclavibacter and Gulosibacter genera have six and seven validly described species, respectively, and have only rarely been documented as etiologic agents of human infections (38, 39).

Pseudoclavibacter and Gulosibacter are aerobic, nonmotile, catalase-positive and chemo-organotrophic and Gram-positive rod-shaped cells. However, Gulosibacter genus may form short filaments and branched cells (37). Due to the taxonomic reclassifications of such microorganisms, there are difficulties in the clinical identification, and sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene is recommended.

sect1.title: Family Micrococcaceae
sect1.para: Currently, theMicrococcaceae family comprises 28 genera. The majority are found in the environment and are not covered in this Manual. The genera Kocuria, Micrococcus, and Nesterenkonia are described in chapter 21.

sect2.title: ■ Genus Arthrobacter and Arthrobacter-Like Genera
sect2.para: The genusArthrobacter included species with phylogenetic and chemotaxonomic heterogeneity due to taxonomic descriptions based on the observation of a rod-coccus life cycle and requirement of strictly aerobic conditions for growth, combined with positive Gram stain and G+C values above 60 mol% (40). Furthermore, several species were described in the genus with incomplete chemotaxonomic studies and/or when an established species of the Arthrobacter genus was identified as the nearest relative by 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis. As a result, several former Arthrobacter species have been reclassified into new genera. This included a taxonomic study that led to an extensive revision of the Arthrobacter genus using phylogenetic analysis, 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities, and cell component composition such as peptidoglycans, quinone systems, and polar lipids. Data allowed the reclassification of Arthrobacter species into five new genera: Glutamicibacter, Paenarthrobacter, Paeniglutamicibacter, Pseudarthrobacter, and Pseudoglutamicibacter (40). Therefore, the genus Arthrobacter sensu stricto became restricted to four species: Arthrobacter globiformis, Arthrobacter pascens, Arthrobacter oryzae, and Arthrobacter humicola. The genus Arthrobacter sensu lato was proposed to include Arthrobacter species which could not be reclassified into new genera (40). Additional studies were carried out and some species of the Arthrobacter sensu lato group were also reclassified into other new genera, including Falsoarthrobacter nasiphocae and Haematomicrobium sanguinis (41, 42).

Recently, a new species was namedArthrobacter ulcerisalmonis, and consequently an emended description of Arthrobacter sensu lato was also done for the inclusion of the peptidoglycan type A11.23, first detected in A. ulcerisalmonis but not in any other Arthrobacter sp. (43).

The genusArthrobacter contains 58 validly published species, mostly isolated from the environment, and only eight Arthrobacter and Arthrobacter-like species have been reported in cases of human infections: Arthrobacter luteolus, Arthrobacter woluwensis, Glutamicibacter creatinolyticus, Haematomicrobium sanguinis, Pseudarthrobacter oxidans, Pseudarthrobacter scleromae, Pseudoglutamicibacter albus, and Pseudoglutamicibacter cumminsii.

sect2.title: ■ Genus Auritidibacter
sect2.para: The genusAuritidibacter currently comprises one species, Auritidibacter ignavus, first isolated from an ear infection (44). A taxonomic study of four strains also recovered from ear discharges was performed by using biochemical and antimicrobial susceptibility assays, cellular fatty acid composition, MALDI-TOF MS, and whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analyses. Data confirmed emendation of the genus and species Auritidibacter ignavus (45).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Rothia
sect2.para: The genusRothia contains 11 validly described species, including Rothia dentocariosa and Rothia mucilaginosa, that may be part of human oral microbiota (1). According to genome-based analyses, the genus Rothia was revised and three species of the genus Kocuria were reclassified as Rothia halotolerans, Rothia koreensis, and Rothia kristinae. Rothia aeria, R. dentocariosa, R. koreensis, R. kristinae, and R. mucilaginosa have been reported as human pathogens causing various types of infections (6).

sect2.title: ■ Genera Cellulosimicrobium and Oerskovia
sect2.para: Cellulosimicrobium and Oerskovia have undergone several taxonomic changes. The genus Cellulosimicrobium was proposed in 2001, based on phylogenetic and chemotaxonomic studies of Cellulomonas cellulans, previously designated as Oerskovia xanthineolytica (5, 46). Based on polyphasic taxonomic studies, researchers re-established the genus Oerskovia for Cellulomonas turbata and reclassified Promicromonospora enterophila as Oerskovia enterophila (47). Moreover, two novel species, Oerskovia jenensis and Oerskovia paurometabola, were proposed. In 2006, some clinical isolates misidentified as Oerskovia turbata were included in the Cellulosimicrobium genus as a new species, Cellulosimicrobium funkei (48). The genus Cellulosimicrobium currently comprises seven species, but only two have been recovered from human infections: C. cellulans and C. funkei. The Oerskovia genus has the same four species as when it was re-established: O. turbata, O. enterophila, O. jenensis, and O. paurometabola (1).

Human infections due toCellulosimicrobium spp. occur in immunocompromised hosts or in patients with indwelling devices, such as intravenous catheters, or foreign bodies (49). The pathogenicity of O. turbata for humans has been difficult to establish, since infections attributed to this species in older case reports were based on phenotypic identification. Many researchers considered O. turbata as a synonym of C. funkei; however, taxonomic studies showed that only part of the lineages named as O. turbata belonged to the species C. funkei. The species O. turbata remains valid.

sect1.title: Family Actinomycetaceae
sect1.para: Other genera are described inchapter 29 of this Manual.

sect2.title: ■ Genera Arcanobacterium and Trueperella
sect2.para: The genusArcanobacterium was described from the reclassified “Corynebacterium haemolyticum” species (50). There are nine validly named Arcanobacterium species. Only Arcanbacterium haemolyticus strains have been reported as pathogens of human infections, mainly in cases of pharyngitis among teenagers and young adults and rarely in cases of osteomyelitis, wounds infections, bacteremia, sepsis, and orbital necrotizing fasciitis (51, 52).

In 2011, five species of genusArcanobacterium were reclassified as members of the new genus Trueperella, including Trueperella abortisuis, Trueperella bernardiae, Trueperella bialowiezensis, Trueperella bonasi, and Trueperella pyogenes (53). Presently, there are six validly described Trueperella species, of which T. bernardiae and T. pyogenes have been mostly reported in cases of human infections (54).

sect1.title: Phylum Bacillota, Class Bacilli, Order Caryophanales, Family Bacillaceae

sect2.title: ■ Genus Exiguobacterium
sect2.para: The genusExiguobacterium includes 19 species, three of which, Exiguobacterium aurantiacum, Exiguobacterium acetylicum, and Exiguobacterium sibiricum, have been associated with human infections (55–57).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Corynebacterium
sect2.para: Corynebacterium is the only genus in the Corynebacteriaceae family. Based on phylogenetic analysis, the Turicella genus was merged with the Corynebacterium genus, and Turicella otitidis was reclassified as Corynebacterium otitidis.

The genusCorynebacterium comprises 136 validly published species, with more than half of these characterized as human pathogens. Therefore, the Corynebacterium genus is considered the main coryneform bacteria of clinical relevance. The type species of this genus is Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the etiologic agent of classic diphtheria. Taxonomic studies have led to the description of novel Corynebacterium species of clinical and veterinary relevance, some of which express MDR profiles.

Corynebacterium species are nonmotile, mostly catalase positive, and facultatively anaerobic. The muramic acid residues of the peptidoglycan are N-acetylated. The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid and mycolic acids, although some species are mycolic acids negative (6, 58).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Corynebacterium spp. may be found in a wide range of ecological niches, such as soil, air, sewage and other sediments, aquatic sources, plant surfaces, and dairy products. Corynebacteria also occur as part of the microbiota of healthy humans and some animals, but presently there is little information on the nature of these corynebacterial species and their host distribution. The genus Corynebacterium encompasses at least 80 species of medical, veterinary, or biotechnological relevance. Nevertheless, most of the novel species described in recent years have originated from human clinical sources due to increasing concern about their potential pathogenic significance. However, there are indications from the implementation of improved molecular taxonomic methodologies that a diversity of new corynebacterial species remains to be discovered from different sources.

Although included among vaccine-preventable diseases, diphtheria remains endemic in some countries. In regions of endemicity, especially in tropical areas, a variety of infections of skin lesions may serve as reservoirs for diphtheria bacilli, including those caused by insect bites and traumas, as well as leishmaniotic and neoplastic ulcers. The transmission ofC. diphtheriae occurs from person to person by droplets of respiratory secretions or by contact with infected skin lesions. Although classically considered a strict human pathogen, C. diphtheriae was found to infect animals, including cats and dogs (59, 60), so companion animals may act as reservoirs for transmission of C. diphtheriae.

The natural habitat of other coryneform bacteria is not fully understood.A. haemolyticum has been recovered from throat as well as from wounds, whereas Trueperella bernardiae has mainly been found in superficial skin abscesses, as well as being a rare cause of infection at other sites (54). Brevibacteria can be recovered from clinical materials, dairy products (e.g., cheese), poultry, and marine and terrestrial habitats, but are also inhabitants of the human skin. Arthrobacter and like genera are thought to be most closely associated with soil samples (40), but at least Pseudoglutamicibacter cumminsii also seems to be present on human skin. Auritidibacter strains have been recovered from ear specimens (44). Members of the genera Exiguobacterium, Oerskovia, Cellulomonas, Cellulosimicrobium, and Microbacterium have their habitats primarily in the environment (e.g., water, soil, and sewage during processing). Microbacterium spp. have also been recovered from hospital environments (61). Curtobacteria have been primarily recovered from plants (62).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Establishing the clinical significance of coryneform bacteria can be difficult for caregivers and microbiologists. This is in part due to the presence of many coryneform bacteria in human microbiota and in the environment.Corynebacterium species and other coryneform bacteria isolated from clinical specimens of patients with health care-related or community-acquired infections, as well as zoonotic and animal infections, remain understudied and underreported in many countries. In the recent past, clinical isolates were frequently considered as contaminants and were neither identified nor tested for antimicrobial susceptibility, even if recovered in pure culture from blood, other sterile body fluids, or deep wound abscesses (63–66).

An overview of human infections linked toCorynebacterium spp. is provided in Table 2. The clinical manifestations of infections with DT-producing species are discussed below. Additional clinical information for non-DT-producing species, mainly case reports and case series, is presented in combination with species characteristics in the “Identification” section of this chapter.

sect2.title: DIPHTHERIA TOXIN-PRODUCING CORYNEBACTERIUM SPP.
sect2.para: C. diphtheriae, Corynebacterium ulcerans, and Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis initially composed a clade of pathogenic species characterized as potentially DT-producing due to lysogenic tox+ corynephages. The “C. diphtheriae complex” was recently defined (67) to include Corynebacterium belfantii (68), Corynebacterium rouxii (67), and Corynebacterium silvaticum in the potentially DT-producing clade (69).

The members of theC. diphtheriae complex have an impact on public health worldwide. C. diphtheriae, C. belfantii, and C. rouxii infect mainly humans (67, 68); C. ulcerans, C. pseudotuberculosis, and C. silvaticum infect mainly wild and domesticated mammals and/or can cause zoonosis (69, 70). The host ranges and virulence mechanisms of these species are not entirely known, and better understanding of these aspects could be helpful in controlling this group of pathogens (64, 71, 72).

sect1.title: Corynebacterium diphtheriae
sect1.para: C. diphtheriae is the main causative agent of classic respiratory and cutaneous diphtheria, a toxemic disease whose prevention depends on effective immunization programs using DT toxoid vaccines (73). Patients with respiratory diphtheria present with an adherent pseudomembrane usually on the mucosa of the throat and pharynx. This is the main characteristic sign of diphtheria. The pseudomembrane can extend to the nose, trachea, bronchi, and bronchioles, leading to severe limitations in airflow and bronchopneumonia. Patients may exhibit a swollen “bull neck.” C. diphtheriae multiplies at the local, superficial site of infection and produces DT that then disseminates through blood, acting in many tissues, most notably the myocardium, central nervous system, kidney, and adrenal glands. Death may result from suffocation by intense local inflammatory effects of DT on the respiratory tract, from pseudomembrane dislodgement, or from systemic effects of DT, mainly myocarditis, renal failure, and neuropathy (64, 74–76).

Respiratory tract infections: sinusitis, tracheobronchitis, pneumonia; bacteremia, sepsis, thrombophlebitis, endocarditis; meningitis; bone and joint infections: spondylitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, synovitis; peritonitis; otitis; ocular and urinary tract infections; skin lesions and surgical wounds; foreign body infections, including mechanically ventilated patients; health care-related outbreaks
Bacteremia, endometritis or pyosalpingitis, cutaneous infection
Granulomastitis, wound infections, abscess, urinary tract infection, peritonitis, osteomyelitis, endocarditis, bacteremia and infections due to use of indwelling medical devices

Urinary tract infections: acute cystitis, pyelonephritis, alkaline encrusted cystitis, encrusted pyelitis; chronic or recurrent cystitis, bacteriuria, bladder stones, and pyelonephritis; bacteremia, sepsis, infections associated with use of indwelling medical devices, endocarditis, encephalitis, pneumonia, osteomyelitis, peritonitis, prostatitis, breast abscesses, skin wounds and soft tissue infections; neonatal umbilical tip infection

sect1.para: aMDR, multidrug-resistant Corynebacterium strains expressing resistance to >3 classes of antimicrobial agents (3).

During the past 2 decades, the increasing number of atypical infections due to non-DT-producing and DT-producingC. diphtheriae strains in partially or nonimmunized persons (adults and children) has become a matter of concern. These have included invasive infections in patients with cancer or indwelling medical devices (77–79). Cases of respiratory diphtheria without pseudomembrane formation in partially immunized children have been reported (80).

In cases of diphtheria, patients should be immediately admitted to a hospital and given diphtheria antitoxin (DAT), consisting of antibodies isolated from the serum of horses that have been challenged with diphtheria toxin, in addition to antibiotics. Since antitoxin does not neutralize toxin that is already bound to tissues, delaying its administration increases risk of death. Therefore, the decision to administer diphtheria antitoxin is based on clinical diagnosis and should not await laboratory diagnosis. Administration of diphtheria vaccine is recommended during convalescence because diphtheria infection does not always confer immunity (73, 75).

Eradication ofC. diphtheriae diseases has not yet been achieved (71). C. diphtheriae, including DT-producing strains, may circulate even in countries with good immunization programs. The introduction of DT-producing strains in a susceptible population may result in diphtheria outbreaks. Moreover, the concentration of protective antibodies decreases by 10% every year. These aspects emphasize the need for vaccination strategies directed at persons of all ages and in different ethnic groups (73, 75). Booster doses of toxoid should be administered at 10-year intervals to maintain protective immunity after childhood immunizations have been completed (63). The efficacy of diphtheric toxoid vaccine or antiserum against diphtheria is a matter of concern. Phylogenetic analyses revealed that the amino acid sequences of the diphtheria toxins from C. diphtheriae strains were identical (81). However, some nontoxigenic, tox gene-bearing C. diphtheriae strains, so-called NTTB strains, are described as unable to produce DT due to variants of the tox gene (82, 83). It should be considered that the vaccination mainly prevents the action of DT and does not impede colonization by C. diphtheriae, especially non-DT-producing strains (71, 81).

sect1.title: Corynebacterium belfantii
sect1.para: Respiratory tract infections byC. belfantii have been described (79), including rhinitis, laryngitis, and pneumonia. Colonization of cystic fibrosis (CF) patients by C. belfantii strains has been reported, including in both asymptomatic patients and patients with exacerbations of respiratory disease. Persistence and transmission of a unique nontoxigenic clone during at least 6 years in a single CF patient care center has been described (68, 84).

sect1.title: Corynebacterium rouxii
sect1.para: C. rouxii is characterized as a human pathogen isolated from patients with osteomyelitis, cutaneous infections, and peritonitis (67). Cases of severe infections due to non-DT-producing C. rouxii strains have been also reported in companion animals, as otitis in cats and purulent orbital cellulitis, otitis, rhinitis, and ulcerative skin lesions in dogs (59, 67, 82).

sect1.title: Corynebacterium ulcerans
sect1.para: C. ulcerans is a potentially DT-producing pathogen that, when it produces DT, causes classic pharyngeal diphtheria and cutaneous diphtheria in humans. Asymptomatic carriers of DT-positive C. ulcerans strains have been reported. Socioeconomic conditions and migration contribute to the incidence, severity, and diversity of types of human infections associated with C. ulcerans (85).

C. ulcerans strains may also produce other clinical syndromes independent of DT production, including pneumonia, pulmonary necrotizing granulomas, disseminated intravascular coagulation, exudative pharyngitis, and cutaneous lesions (86). C. ulcerans isolates from human wound skin infections were verified to be MDR (87).

Some isolates ofC. ulcerans and C. diphtheria produce a toxin with structural similarity to Shiga-like toxins, independent of DT. This toxin includes a putative ribosome-binding protein (Rbp), and it has been shown to be cytotoxic in vitro and to be associated with virulence in model systems (71). C. ulcerans producing this toxin was isolated from an elderly patient with fatal pulmonary infection due to hematogenic dissemination from primary nonhealing skin ulcers (88). This isolate was resistant to both penicillin and clindamycin.

C. ulcerans is primarily a pathogen of animals. Cases of infections or detection of C. ulcerans strains in otherwise healthy animals have been described in various species, including domestic cats and dogs (85, 89, 90).

Although DT is highly conserved inC. diphtheriae, this is not the case in DT-producing C. ulcerans. The diphtheria toxoid vaccine is produced from DT of C. diphtheriae Park-Williams Number 8 strain. DT diversification in C. ulcerans may decrease the efficacy of diphtheria vaccine and diphtheria antitoxin for prevention and treatment of DT-producing C. ulcerans strains (81).

sect1.title: Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis
sect1.para: C. pseudotuberculosis is a zoonotic pathogen that causes abscesses and ulcerative lymphangitis in several types of animals. C. pseudotuberculosis biovar ovis infects mainly sheep and goats, and C. pseudotuberculosis biovar equi infects horses, cattle, and pigs (91).

Human infections are infrequent, and most of the reported cases were due to animal exposures in farm and veterinary workers, butchers, and travelers to rural areas. Most reported cases involve lymphadenopathy caused by DT-negativeC. pseudotuberculosis strains. One case of human infection due to a DT-producing C. pseudotuberculosis strain has been reported in the literature. The zoonotic pathogen was isolated from the aortic root vegetation of an injecting drug user with endocarditis. Although C. pseudotuberculosis infection is typically associated with contact with cattle, sheep, and goats, this patient had no history of animal contact and no possible source of infection was identified (86). Some C. pseudotuberculosis strains isolated from human infections were MDR (87).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Laboratory procedures for identification ofCorynebacterium spp. and other coryneform bacteria include collection and transport of clinical samples, isolation practices, culture conditions, phenotypic and molecular assays, as well as antimicrobial susceptibility testing. If antimicrobial therapy has already been started, clinical specimens for culture should still be taken (73–76).
In general,Corynebacterium spp. and other coryneform bacteria do not need special handling when clinical samples are collected and transported.

The diagnosis of diphtheria is primarily a clinical one, and physicians should notify the receiving laboratory immediately if a specimen was taken from a patient with suspected diphtheria infection. In case of respiratory diphtheria, material for culture should be obtained on a swab (either a cotton- or a polyester-tipped swab) from the inflamed areas in the oropharynx and nasopharynx. Swabs should be immediately transferred to the microbiology laboratory for culturing. Swabs from beneath the membrane are the most valuable; however, those obtained from infected patients may still be negative. Multisite sampling is thought to increase sensitivity. Removal of membranes should not be performed, to prevent the spread of DT. If membranes are eventually removed, they should also be sent to the microbiology laboratory. It is preferable that materials be collected prior to initiating antibiotic treatment. Nasopharyngeal swabs should be obtained from suspected carriers, despite a low sensitivity rate for recovery (63, 73). In cases of classic or zoonotic diphtheria and isolation of DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. strains, mandatory toxigenicity tests should be done. If antimicrobial therapy has already been initiated, clinical specimens should still be collected and transferred to the microbiology laboratory for culturing and detection of the tox gene and identification of diphtheria pathogens by PCR methods, as described below (63, 73, 74, 76, 92).

All coryneform bacteria are relatively resistant to drying and moderate temperature changes. If the swabs must be sent to the laboratory after a delay, the use of a semisolid transport medium ensures the maintenance of the bacteria. Amies or other effective transport media can be used forC. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, and C. pseudotuberculosis. Silica gel has been used as a transport medium in limited-resource settings; the desiccated swabs need to be incubated overnight in broth (supplemented with either plasma or blood), which should then be streaked onto the primary plating medium, and plates are read after 18 to 24 h of incubation at 37°C, preferably in a 5% CO2-enriched atmosphere (63, 75, 93).

Long-term preservation in skim milk at −70°C is applicable to all coryneform bacteria. The same skim milk tube, except for those containing lipophilic corynebacteria, can be thawed and put into the freezer again. For both nonhydrophilic and lipophilic coryneforms, good results were observed with Microbank tubes (Pro Lab Diagnostics). Coryneform bacteria can also be stored for decades when they are kept lyophilized in an appropriate medium (e.g., 0.9% NaCl containing 2% bovine serum albumin) (63, 73).

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: The Gram stain of patient specimens can provide initial information suggesting the presence of coryneform bacteria. Gram staining demonstrates irregular Gram-positive rods presenting as single cells, pairs, clusters, or long filamentous forms (Fig. 1). C. diphtheriae strains present variable and often-described club-shaped bacilli that may be arranged as single cells, in pairs, in palisades, or in clusters with angular V-shaped forms (Fig. 1a). Corynebacterium spp. may also exhibit coccobacillary and/or long filament forms as single cells, in pairs, or in clusters (Fig. 1e–g). Other coryneform genera may exhibit cell morphology similar to most Corynebacterium spp., including variable Gram staining and also presenting coccoidal forms, thin, short rods, aggregative cells, hyphae-like and filamentous forms, and rod-coccus life cycle (Fig. 1b–d and 1h). Albert-Laybourn staining procedures to demonstrate the presence of polymetaphosphate metachromatic granules are no longer routinely performed in most laboratories (63, 94). Initial diagnosis of diphtheria based on microscopic observation of swabs and smears may be accomplished, but further laboratory identification procedures are required (80, 94, 95).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Gram stain morphologies of (a) Corynebacterium diphtheriae ATCC 14779 after 48 h of incubation; (b) Turicella otitidis DSM 8821T (48 h); (c) Dermabacter hominis ATCC 51325 (48 h); (d) Gardnerella vaginalis ATCC 14018T (48 h); (e) Corynebacterium amycolatum NML 92-0507 (24 h); (f) Corynebacterium matruchotii ATCC 14266T (24 h); (g) Corynebacterium coyleae NML 98-0068 (24 h); and (h) black-pigmented Rothia dentocariosa NML77-0298 (24 h).

sect2.para: Extraction of bacterial DNA from swabs for detection of thetox gene by PCR for identification of diphtheria pathogens may be performed (63, 92).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Corynebacterium spp. and other coryneform bacilli grow well on 5% sheep blood agar (SBA) media, depending on the base culture medium used. Most Corynebacterium species can be selected using a 5% SBA-based medium containing 100 μg/ml of fosfomycin, as this group of bacteria is highly resistant to this compound. It is also possible to put disks containing 50 μg of fosfomycin (plus 50 μg of glucose-6-phosphate already incorporated in the disk) on an SBA or a colistin-nalidixic acid (CNA) plate and then examine the colonies which grow around the disk. Selective media for coryneform bacteria containing 50 to 100 μg/ml of furazolidone have also been described. However, human pathogens described to date did not grow on MacConkey agar (94, 96).

Lipophilic coryneform bacteria can be grown using culture media with 0.1 to 1.0% Tween 80 (63, 94). If lipophilic Corynebacterium spp. are suspected (for example C. jeikeium, C. tuberculostearicum, C. urealyticum, or C. kroppenstedtii), then 0.1 to 1.0% Tween 80 could be added to an SBA plate (add Tween 80 before pouring the medium). Lipophilia can be tested for by two methods: (i) colonies are subcultured onto SBA and onto a 0.1 to 1% Tween 80-containing SBA plate; lipophilic corynebacteria develop colonies up to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h on Tween-supplemented agar; (ii) coryneform bacteria are subcultured in brain heart infusion broth with and without supplementation of 1% (vol/vol) of sterile Tween 80; lipophilic strains only grow in the supplemented broth (63, 94).

Primary isolation ofC. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, and other potentially toxigenic species should be performed using nonselective 5% SBA and a selective medium such as tellurite media, cystine tellurite blood agar, blood tellurite agar, or chocolate tellurite agar (63, 73). Tellurite supplement in these media inhibits the growth of many noncoryneform bacteria, particularly those found in respiratory tract specimens. A few C. diphtheriae strains have been found to be sensitive to tellurite and therefore may not grow on CTBA but may grow on SBA (96).

The best medium for direct culturing ofC. diphtheriae is probably Tinsdale medium. Limitations of this agar include its relatively short shelf life (<4 weeks) and the necessity of adding horse serum. On Tinsdale plates (Fig. 2i), both tellurite reductase activity (as shown by black colonies) and cystinase activity (as shown by a brown halo around the colonies) can be detected. If neither CTBA nor Tinsdale medium is available, CNA plates are recommended for the isolation of C. diphtheriae or any other coryneform bacteria. Other Corynebacterium spp. may grow and may produce brownish to black (albeit smaller) colonies on Tinsdale medium, but strains of those species will lack the distinctive halo around each colony. It is necessary to pick multiple colonies from CNA plates to rule out C. diphtheriae (63).

Microbiologists should redouble attention in potential cases of diphtheria and invasive infections due toC. diphtheriae of patients that were partially immunized and/or who previously received antibiotic therapy. In these cases, only a single colony of C. diphtheriae may be detected when using the nonselective SBA medium (96).

With the exceptions of some arthrobacters, microbacteria, and curtobacteria, which may have optimal growth temperatures between 30°C and 35°C, the medically relevant coryneform bacteria all grow at 37°C. It is desirable to culture specimens for coryneform bacteria in a CO2-enriched atmosphere, since some members of some genera, e.g., Rothia, Arcanobacterium, and Trueperella, may grow better under those conditions.

Nearly all medically relevant coryneform bacteria grow within 48 h. However, it is suggested that the primary isolation plates be retained for at least 72 h to assess bacterial growth of lipophilic corynebacteria incubated aerobically and anaerobically.

figure.title: FIGURE 2 Colony morphologies of different coryneform bacteria after 48 h of incubation on SBA. (a) C. amycolatum NML (LCDC) 91-0077; (b) C. diphtheriae ATCC 14779; (c) C. mucifaciens NML (LCDC) 97-0202; (d) C. striatum ATCC 6940T; (e) D. hominis ATCC 51325; (f) R. dentocariosa NML (LCDC) 95-0154; (g) C. aurimucosum NML (LCDC) 91-0032 (after 96 h); (h) black-pigmented Rothia dentocariosa NML (LCDC)77-0298 (after 96 h); (i) C. diphtheriae biovar gravis colonies on a Tinsdale agar plate (photo kindly provided by C. Hinnebusch and M. Cohen, UCLA School of Medicine, Los Angeles, CA); (j) Oerskovia species with substrate, showing pseudohyphae.

sect2.para: If liquid media are used (e.g., for specimens from normally sterile body sites), these should be checked after 5 days for turbidity and, if turbid, by Gram staining for the presence of coryneform bacteria before being discarded. It is also recommended that urine specimens be incubated for longer than 24 h to check for the presence of those slower-growingCorynebacterium spp. linked to urinary tract infections (C. urealyticum, C. ureicelerivorans, C. glucuronolyticum, C. aurimucosum, and others). Patients infected with these species are generally symptomatic, have advanced age, have a urinary catheter or other foreign device, have alkaline urine or struvite crystals in their urine sediment, or have had genitourinary surgery (66).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Infections due toCorynebacterium spp. and other pathogenic coryneform species occur in all body sites, whether as single species or in polymicrobial infections. Accurate laboratory diagnosis of diphtheria is an important public health issue, and so there is an urgent need for reliable and rapid laboratory methods for identification of DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. Routine procedures for identification of C. diphtheriae and C. ulcerans and other DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. are uncommon in diagnostic laboratories in many countries, due to a low prevalence of diphtheria and/or the need for cost-effectiveness (80, 97).

Coryneform bacteria should be identified to the species level if they are isolated from normally sterile body sites and from aseptically collected clinical material, such as deep wounds or prosthetic devices, when they are the sole or predominant microorganism. Coryneform bacteria in urine cultures should be identified and considered as potential pathogens if they are pure and present with bacterial count >104/ml and if they are the predominant organisms with total bacterial count >105/ml (79). On the other hand, coryneform bacteria should be reported as members of the normal microbiome when they are grown from normally nonsterile sites in numbers equal to or smaller than those of resident microbiota.

The Gram stain may provide useful information for identification of coryneform bacteria, sometimes allowing preliminary identification to the genus level (Fig. 1). Basic information, such as the time taken to observe growth, morphology, size, pigment, and hemolysis of colonies, provides valuable information for identification of coryneform bacteria (Fig. 2).

sect1.title: Screening Tests and Biochemical Characterization
sect1.para: Methods and identification schemes based on biochemical testing forCorynebacterium spp. remain strategically used, such as for a description of new species or by smaller centers which lack molecular or rapid identification systems (63, 98). Biochemical assays and other phenotypic procedures for testing clinically relevant Corynebacterium spp. are outlined in Table 3.

Screening tests include CAMP reaction (24-h incubation) (Fig. 3a) and DNase assay. The reverse CAMP test is useful as part of the identification of C. ulcerans and C. pseudotuberculosis. A reverse CAMP test is based on the inhibition of hemolytic activity of beta-hemolysin from S. aureus through the production of phospholipase D (PLD) by C. ulcerans and C. pseudotuberculosis (98). The use of DNase as a screening test may provide substantial improvement in the existing identification algorithm of DT-producing Corynebacterium species in routine diagnostic laboratories. DNase assays, after a 24- to 48-h incubation period, have been useful for differentiating DNase-positive C. diphtheriae and C. ulcerans from DNase-negative C. pseudotuberculosis and other pathogenic corynebacteria. This is particularly useful in the surveillance for cases of diphtheria, asymptomatic carriers, and invasive infections in endemic or epidemic areas with limited resources (99). Tinsdale medium, which enables detection of the enzyme cystinase, may be useful, as only C. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, and C. pseudotuberculosis produce the characteristic black colonies surrounded by a brown halo after overnight incubation (63, 73). Phenotypic tests and procedures for processing suspect C. diphtheriae and C. ulcerans may be performed by conventional biochemical assays, semiautomated systems, API-Coryne System (bioMérieux), and automated VITEK 2 (bioMérieux). However, conventional and commercial devices for biochemical identification may fail to accurately differentiate and identify coryneform bacteria.
