Adapted from reference 62.

figure.title: FIGURE 3 (a) CAMP reactions after 24 h. (Top) C. glucuronolyticum DMMZ 891 (positive reaction). (Middle) C. diphtheriae ATCC 14779 (negative reaction). (Bottom) A. haemolyticum ATCC 9345T (CAMP inhibition reaction). The vertical streak is S. aureus ATCC 25923. (b) Elek test after 48 h. Clockwise from top: C. xerosis ATCC 373T, negative control; C. diphtheriae ATCC 27012 (C7s strain), a strong toxin producer (strongly positive); patient isolate NML 130346, identified by rpoB sequencing as C. ulcerans; C. diphtheriae ATCC 19409 (NCTC 3984), a weak toxin producer (weakly positive); duplicate of patient isolate; duplicate of strong positive. The center disk contains diphtheria antitoxin. When strain toxin and diphtheria antitoxin react, they form a visible precipitin line in agar observed between the isolate and disk; the negative control does not form a line. Some strong toxin producers are positive at or before 24 h, and weak producers are usually positive at 48 h. Precipitin lines can be visually enhanced by incubating up to 72 h; nontoxigenic strains do not show precipitin at 48 to 72 h.

sect1.para: Molecular techniques have been increasingly used in microbiology laboratories for the identification ofCorynebacterium species and other coryneform bacteria. One manufacturer, GenMark Diagnostics, Inc. (now Roche, Inc., Carlsbad, CA), has incorporated identification of Corynebacterium species in its Gram-positive identification panel performed on positive blood culture bottles (100). This genus-level target was incorporated as a potential marker for contamination along with Bacillus species, Lactobacillus, and Cutibacterium acnes. The sensitivity compared to standard-of-care methods in one multicenter study was 84.5% and the specificity was 99.9%. Results may have been impacted by the inability of standard-of-care methods to identify organisms to the species level. Also, per the manufacturer’s instructions for use, the assay is not designed to detect C. amycolatum, C. argentoratense, C. bovis, C. durum, C. glucuronolyticum, C. macginleyi, C. propinquum, C. riegelii, or C. sundsvallense (GenMark ePlex Blood Culture Identification Gram-Positive [BCID_GP] Panel Package Insert, 2020).

sect1.title: MALDI-TOF MS Systems
sect1.para: The implementation of microbial identification by MALDI-TOF MS in clinical laboratories contributes to faster and more reliable identification of microorganisms, including coryneform bacteria. Numerous studies have suggested that MALDI-TOF MS reliably identifies ~90% of medically relevantCorynebacterium isolates to species level, with a lower accuracy for identification of other coryneforms (63, 101, 102). As found with other automated identification systems, species which are closely related by 16S rRNA gene sequencing (~>99% identity) may also be difficult to differentiate by MALDI-TOF MS. Currently C. belfantii, C. rouxii, and C. silvaticum, as well as newly described non-DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. and other various coryneform bacilli characterized as human pathogens, may not yet have been incorporated in the standard databases of MALDI-TOF MS systems used in routine diagnostics (59, 103).

Identification ofCorynebacterium spp. and some coryneforms directly from positive blood culture bottles, then processed using a MALDI-TOF MS system after use of a lysis method (Sepsityper; bioMérieux) or smudge plate approach, can be attempted, but these incur additional costs and extraction time, and they yield poorer-than-expected matches to spectra in the MALDI-TOF MS identification systems for Gram-positive taxa (63, 104).

sect1.title: Sequence-Based Identification Methods Using Single or Multiple Gene Targets
sect1.para: Sequence-based identification is indicated for definitive taxonomic investigations of all coryneforms described in this chapter, including taxa where the bacterium was not satisfactorily identified by biochemical testing alone or where MALDI-TOF MS identification gave rise to no reliable identification or provided high-confidence scores for more than one species.

Determination of a complete or nearly complete 16S rRNA gene sequence is a rational approach for identifyingCorynebacterium spp., since most established species exhibit 3% or greater divergence from each other except for C. afermentans, C. coyleae, and C. mucifaciens (<2%); C. aurimucosum, C. minutissimum, and C. singulare (<2%); C. sundsvallense and C. thomssenii (<1.5%); C. ulcerans and C. pseudotuberculosis (<1% to each other, both <2% to C. diphtheriae); C. propinquum and C. pseudodiphtheriticum (<2%); C. xerosis, C. freneyi, and C. hansenii (<2%); and C. macginleyi and C. accolens (<2%) (105). A very useful approach for resolving the identification of Corynebacterium spp. that cannot be resolved by 16S rRNA sequencing is sequencing a fragment of the rpoB gene (using primers designated C2700F and C3130R), since this particular region of the gene displays a high degree of polymorphism within the genus Corynebacterium (106, 107). A divergence of >5% within this particular part of the rpoB gene of two strains suggests that they belong to two different species.

sect1.title: Methods Used for Detection of tox Gene and Diphtheria Toxin Production
sect1.para: Different molecular methods, such as end-point and real-time PCR, have been used for the characterization ofC. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, and C. pseudotuberculosis strains. Nevertheless, phenotypic testing is required for confirmation of DT expression. DT production by isolates that test positive for the gene for DT must be confirmed by using the Elek test, while isolates not bearing the tox gene may be rapidly reported as nontoxigenic (73). Phenotypic confirmation of DT production is needed because non-DT-producing but tox-bearing (NTTB) variants have been found with various mutations that prevent toxin production (83).

Although allC. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, and C. pseudotuberculosis with PCR positive results for the tox gene will be tested by the Elek test, detection of tox gene by PCR should immediately be reported to caregivers, without waiting for the Elek result (73, 75). Multiplex PCR represents a fast, simple, and reliable methodology for the detection of tox gene from potentially DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. Identification can be performed using 16S rRNA sequencing from both C. pseudotuberculosis and C. ulcerans, pld from C. pseudotuberculosis, dtxR from C. diphtheriae, and rpoB from Corynebacterium spp.

Phenotypic testing by Elek tests (conventional or modified) and Vero cell cytotoxicity assays has been used to detect DT production by clinical isolates, mostly in reference laboratories (73). The most used modified Elek immunoprecipitation test is performed by placing a disk overlaid with diphtheria antitoxin (10 IU/disk) on an Elek plate inoculated with control and test strains. As antitoxin diffuses through the agar, it forms a precipitin line only with diphtheria toxin-producing isolates, as illustrated in Fig. 3b. It is recommended that multiple colonies of C. diphtheriae and related species be tested for DT production by modified Elek methods (108).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION: DESCRIPTIONS OF CORYNEBACTERIUM SPECIES
sect2.para: Corynebacterium spp. have been characterized by using phenotypic, molecular, chemical, and genetic methods. Based on the analysis of reported studies, a range of hitherto lesser-known Corynebacterium spp. are described in this section. Table 3 outlines some phenotypic and metabolic features of DT-producing and non-DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. Species described in these tables and in the text below grow well in 24 h on standard media and at incubation temperatures, unless described in the text below as lipophilic.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium diphtheriae
sect2.para: Colonies ofC. diphtheriae are somewhat dry and gray-white and 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h at 37°C (Fig. 2b); hemolysis is variable (63). The organism is positive for glucose and maltose, glycogen and sucrose variable (109), and nitrate variable (110). C. diphtheriae was classically divided into four biovars: gravis, mitis, belfanti, and intermedius, defined by differences in colony morphology and biochemical characteristics. C. diphtheriae biovar gravis reduces nitrate and utilizes both glycogen and starch; biovar intermedius is somewhat lipophilic in that colonies are 0.5 to 1 mm after 24 to 48 h growth on blood agar, but otherwise reduces nitrate and may utilize glycogen and starch; biovar mitis reduces nitrate but does not utilize glycogen and rarely starch; biovar belfanti neither reduces nitrate nor utilizes glycogen or starch (Table 3).

C. diphtheriae strains could not be differentiated to biovars based on analysis of WGS data (111). A comparative genomic analysis of a clinical isolate with other publicly available genomes of C. diphtheriae characterized two clades of C. diphtheriae: C. diphtheriae subsp. diphtheriae and C. diphtheriae subsp. lausannense. Interestingly, C. diphtheriae subsp. lausannense strains lacked genes of the nitrate reductase but displayed a larger genome size and various mechanisms of horizontal gene transfer. C. diphtheriae subsp. lausannense strains were subsequently isolated primarily from the respiratory tract of individuals from different countries (110). Moreover, nitrate-negative C. diphtheriae biovar belfanti strains were recently classified as two novel species, C. belfantii and C. rouxii (67, 68).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium belfantii
sect2.para: As already mentioned, the inability to reduce nitrate distinguishesC. belfantii from C. diphtheriae and most biovars of this species. C. belfantii does not ferment glycogen, a variable characteristic of C. diphtheriae (68). Recent investigations by genomic sequencing, biochemical, and chemotaxonomic analyses have indicated that C. diphtheriae biovar belfanti represents a branch that is demarcated from C. diphtheriae biovars mitis and gravis. Consequently, the name C. belfantii for the group of nitrate-negative strains, previously considered as C. diphtheriae biovar belfanti, was suggested (68). The tox gene was only rarely reported in isolates of biovar belfanti, and no strain of C. belfantii or C. diphtheriae subsp. lausannense has been described as tox positive (67, 68, 82).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium rouxii
sect2.para: C. rouxii exhibits biochemical features of C. diphtheriae strains, previously characterized as biovar belfanti, except that it does not ferment lactose. Four genes of the maltose utilization pathway were present and undisrupted in six C. rouxii strains, as in other members of the C. diphtheriae complex (67).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium ulcerans
sect2.para: Colonies are somewhat dry and gray-white and 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h at 37°C.C. ulcerans may be differentiated from C. diphtheriae by urease activity and reverse CAMP (Fig. 3a); it may be differentiated from C. pseudotuberculosis by source, biochemically, and by partial rpoB gene but not 16S rRNA gene sequencing. Strains of C. ulcerans are positive for glycogen, starch, and trehalose fermentation. WGS has provided insight into genes coding for various virulence factors, including production of phospholipase D (PLD) and Shiga-like toxin RBP (89).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis
sect2.para: C. pseudotuberculosis colonies are yellowish white, opaque, convex, and about 1 mm in diameter after 24 h. DNase screening test may be used to separate DNase-negative C. pseudotuberculosis from DNase-positive C. ulcerans strains (99). C. pseudotuberculosis strains are classified into two biovars based on nitrate reductase activities: C. pseudotuberculosis biovar ovis is negative for nitrate reduction while C. pseudotuberculosis biovar equi is positive for nitrate reduction (91).

sect1.title: Non-Diphtheria Toxin-Producing Corynebacterium Spp.
sect1.para: As mentioned above, the clinical significance of these species is discussed with the identification.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium accolens
sect2.para: C. accolens is associated with varied types of infections, including nasal necrosis, osteomyelitis, and myositis following trauma, bone fracture, and breast abscess (112–114). The pathogen may be isolated from children and adults with chronic tonsillitis and nasopharyngitis (115). Ventilator-associated C. accolens pneumonia may also occur in patients with respiratory failure due to COVID-19 (116).
Colonies are, as for all other lipophilicCorynebacterium spp., convex, smooth, and <0.5 mm in diameter on SBA medium after 24 h of incubation at 37°C, pH 7.2.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium afermentans
sect2.para: C. afermentans subsp. afermentans may be part of the skin microbiota, but is clinically significant when isolated from blood cultures and abscesses (117), while C. afermentans subsp. lipophilum has been mainly found in bacteremia and infections of superficial wounds (118). C. afermentans may be MDR (119, 120).

C. afermentans subsp. afermentans is nonlipophilic, while C. afermentans subsp. lipophilum is lipophilic. C. afermentans subsp. afermentans strains grown on bacteriological culture agar media exhibit whitish, convex, creamy colonies, 1 to 1.5 mm diameter after 24 h of incubation. Colonies of C. afermentans subsp. lipophilum strains are typical of lipophilic corynebacteria: convex, smooth, and <0.5 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium amycolatum
sect2.para: C. amycolatum is part of the cutaneous microbiota of healthy adults. Nevertheless, it is one of the most commonly reported Corynebacterium spp. as causative agent of heath care-related and community-acquired infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent patients, including fatal infections in premature infants (77, 98, 121). C. amycolatum strains can cause different types of infections, especially in patients with underlying risk factors and comorbidities. These include sepsis, bacteremia with high mortality and morbidity rates (122), endocarditis of prosthetic and native valves (123), infections related to invasive indwelling medical devices, and following vascular graft implantation, prosthetic joint insertion, orbital implant, and open fractures, among others (124–129). C. amycolatum is also recognized as a pathogen of several types of infections in adult cancer patients (79) as well as bloodstream and venous catheter-related infections in pediatric inpatients with hematological cancer (77).
Colonies are very typically dry, waxy, and grayish white with irregular edges and are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation (Fig. 2a). C. amycolatum strains are usually MDR (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium appendicis
sect2.para: C. appendicis was isolated from an abscess of a patient with appendicitis. Colonies are dry, very small (diameter <0.5 mm), slightly grayish, and nonhemolytic when grown on Columbia blood agar supplemented with 5% SBA after 2 days of incubation at 37°C. Larger, slightly creamy colonies are obtained when bacterial cells are grown on brain heart infusion agar and on Trypticase soy agar supplemented with 1% Tween 80. The organism is facultatively anaerobic and catalase positive (3, 63, 130).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium aquatimens
sect2.para: C. aquatimens was isolated from blood cultures of a patient with bacteremia. This species grows very slowly with air, but enhanced growth is obtained in 5% CO2-enriched atmosphere. On Columbia blood agar, colonies are dry, grayish, and circular with entire margins, up to 1.0 mm in diameter after 48 h at 37°C. The organism is lipophilic and grows on BHI agar supplemented with 1% Tween 80, producing creamy-colored colonies which are 2 to 4 mm in diameter. The organism is catalase positive, oxidase negative, and nonhemolytic. CAMP reaction is negative (131).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium argentoratense
sect2.para: C. argentoratense is part of the human skin and tongue microbiota. Most infections reported have been of the upper and lower respiratory tract, although other types of infections occur, including recurrent and/or chronic otitis media in children. C. argentoratense strains may be MDR (3, 63, 132).

Phenotypic, molecular characterization and draft genome sequence ofC. argentoratense strains also characterized colonies on SBA as nonhemolytic, slightly rough and cream colored, and 2 mm in diameter after 48 h of incubation in air at 35°C (63, 132).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium aurimucosum
sect2.para: C. aurimucosum has been observed in the female urogenital microbiota. Cases of urinary tract infections, among others, have occurred mostly in male patients, and female urogenital tract infections have been associated with complications during pregnancy, including spontaneous abortion (101, 133, 134). C. aurimucosum clinical isolates may be MDR (3).

C. aurimucosum is a facultative anaerobe that usually presents slightly yellowish and sticky colonies on 5% SBA plates. C. nigricans brown-black-pigmented strains were assigned to C. aurimucosum species, and so some strains exibit this pigment (Fig. 2g). These pigmented isolates are mainly recovered from the female urogenital tract (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium auris
sect2.para: C. auris is mostly isolated from the external ear canal and middle ear fluid of patients with otitis and from blood of hospitalized patients with bacteremia. Colonies of C. auris on solid media are dryish and slightly adherent to agar, becoming slightly yellowish with time, with 1 to 2 mm diameter after 48 h of incubation (135).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium auriscanis
sect2.para: C. auriscanis, found in the oral cavity of dogs, is characterized as a causative agent of canine diseases (136) and may also be isolated from wound infections in humans after a dog bite (63, 137).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium bovis
sect2.para: C. bovis strains have been reported to be pathogenic to cattle and rodents, as well as etiologic agents of different types of human infections (138, 139). MDR C. bovis may survive as biofilms in hospitals and cause health care-related infections (87). Moreover, recent contact with cows of a patient presenting with ocular infection (keratitis and corneal perforation) suggests that the source of C. bovis was infected cattle (138).
Colonies on nutrient agar supplemented with 0.1% Tween 80 are white to cream, circular, entire, slightly shiny, ~1 to 2 mm in diameter; facultative anaerobic; and lipophilic (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium canis
sect2.para: C. canis was isolated from a wound infection caused by a dog bite. C. canis grows as domed colonies adherent to agar. Gram stain showed filamentous rods (>15 μm in length) and some bacterial cells exhibiting branching (63, 140).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium confusum
sect2.para: C. confusum has been isolated from different types of human infections and from genitourinary infections in pigs. C. confusum strains were also found in bulk tank raw cow’s milk of dairy farms (141), suggesting a possible zoonotic transmission.

C. confusum may be MDR, as previously verified for a strain isolated from raw cow’s milk (141). Colonies on agar media are whitish, glistening, convex, and creamy and grow up to 1.5 mm in diameter after 48 h of incubation at 37°C.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium coyleae
sect2.para: AlthoughC. coyleae may be part of the microbiota of the bladder from healthy individuals, pathogenic strains have been associated with complicated urinary tract infections and with urgency urinary incontinence and overactive bladder (142). C. coyleae strains may be MDR (3). Health care-related infections, including bilateral nephrectomy due to a complicated urinary tract infection in a patient with history of chronic kidney failure, have been reported (143).

C. coyleae strains cultivated on agar medium for 24 h of incubation exhibit growth as creamy or sticky, whitish, and slightly glistening colonies 1 mm in diameter; there is very poor anaerobic growth.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium durum
sect2.para: C. durum is most frequently isolated from the throat rather than the nasopharynx of healthy adults (121, 144). C. durum strains have been recovered from sputum, gingival margin and subgingival plaque, blood, and a foot abscess (145).

Colonies grown on agar medium are only 0.5 to 1 mm in diameter after aerobic incubation for 72 h. The organism forms long and filamentous rods, with occasional bulges. The original description of this bacterium cited beige and rough colonies with convolutions, an irregular margin, and strong adherence to agar if grown under aerobic conditions, but some strains are smoother and not adherent to agar (63, 144).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium falsenii
sect2.para: C. falsenii, a potentially zoonotic pathogen spread from birds, has been isolated from blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid of patients with bacteremia, including children (146).

Colonies are whitish and smooth, with entire edges, and are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h. After 72 h, most strains exhibit a yellowish pigment, which intensifies with time. The cell wall containsmeso-diaminopimelic acid and mycolic acids (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium flavescens
sect2.para: C. flavescens may cause trichomycosis in humans, a superficial infection which primarily affects axillary hairs (147). Colonies grown on brain heart infusion agar are smooth and cream colored. A yeasty odor is associated with growth on galactose agar plates.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium fournieri
sect2.para: C. fournierii was identified in a case of vaginosis in a 21-year-old patient. Bacterial cells were facultative anaerobic with growth observed between 25 and 40°C in anaerobic and aerobic conditions on Columbia agar with 5% sheep blood. Optimal growth was observed after 48 h at 37°C in aerobic conditions. Growth was found to occur from pH 6.0 up to 8.0 and 0 to 5% NaCl. Surface colonies on blood agar were observed to be circular, glistening, and slightly grayish with an approximate diameter of 1 mm (148).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium frankenforstense
sect2.para: C. frankenforstense preferentially colonizes chronic wounds. Biofilm formation by pathogenic C. frankenforstense strains significantly enhances the ability to colonize chronic wounds and severely compromise wound healing processes (149). Colonies on Trypticase agar medium after 3 days of incubation under aerobic conditions at 30°C are about 2 mm in diameter, white, entire-edged, and shiny, and nonhemolytic on Columbia blood agar medium.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium freiburgense
sect2.para: C. freiburgense was recovered from a human wound following a dog bite. Five-day-old colonies in 5 % CO2 conditions exhibit a very peculiar “spoke-wheel” morphology. Colonies are also strongly adherent to blood agar (63, 150).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium freneyi
sect2.para: C. freneyi, initially recovered from skin, has been recovered from a variety of clinical specimens, as well as different types of infections, including granulomatous mastitis, bacteremia, and prosthetic valve endocarditis (151, 152). A case of exudative pharyngitis with suspected diphtheria was recently reported (153). C. freneyi strains may be MDR (3). C. freneyi strains have been also associated with cases of infections in dogs and other animals (136).

Colonies are typically wrinkled, whitish, dry, and rough; they have irregular edges and are 0.5 to 1 mm in diameter after 48 h of incubation.C. freneyi strains also exhibit growth at 20°C, glucose fermentation at 42°C, and α-glucosidase activity (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium glucuronolyticum
sect2.para: C. glucuronolyticum may be isolated from the microbiota of the female reproductive tract (105, 154, 155). C. glucuronolyticum strains characterized as human pathogens may be MDR (3) and have been mainly isolated from male genitourinary infections (151, 156). Eye infections in patients with persistent corneal epithelial defects due to comorbidities have been reported (157). Colonies are nonhemolytic, whitish-yellowish, convex, creamy, and 1 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation (63, 156).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium gottingense
sect2.para: C. gottingense strains were isolated from urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and blood samples of patients with bacteremia (158). Strains can grow in a wide range of temperatures but best at 35 to 37°C. Colonies appear as white-cream, circular, and convex with shiny smooth surfaces on Columbia blood agar (158).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium hansenii
sect2.para: C. hansenii was isolated from pus from an elderly patient with a severe thigh liposarcoma infection. Colonies were yellow pigmented, very small (0.5 to 1.0 mm diameter), dry, and rough when cultured aerobically on SBA in an atmosphere with 10% CO2 (159).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium hindlerae
sect2.para: C. hindlerae was recently isolated from a wrist granuloma. C. hindlerae forms black colonies and black halos on modified Tinsdale medium but is not closely related to C. diphtheriae and related taxa (160).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium imitans
sect2.para: C. imitans was originally isolated from a nasopharyngeal specimen from a child suspected of having diphtheria as well as from three adult contacts (161). This was the first well-documented case of person-to-person transmission of a Corynebacterium species other than C. diphtheriae in a nonhospital setting. C. imitans has been recovered from urine and blood, including from a patient with suspected bacteremia (162).

Colonies on agar media are whitish-grayish, glistening with entire edges, creamy, and 1 to 2 mm in diameter.C. imitans strains grow as brown-black (tellurite reductase positive) colonies but do not produce a brown halo on Tinsdale medium.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium jeikeium
sect2.para: C. jeikeium is usually present in skin microbiota and can also colonize the conjunctiva and nose of humans (163). C. jeikeium is usually MDR and causes varied types of infections in immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients, including patients with hematologic malignancy, neutropenia, or AIDS, and following bone marrow transplant (77, 79, 98, 105, 157, 164).

C. jeikeium infections in immunocompromised cancer patients can be challenging due to multidrug resistance, high virulence, and rapid skin colonization, especially those attended at hospital units (intensive, nonintensive, and other units providing specialty care). MDR C. jeikeium strains may be part of the skin microbiota of hospitalized personnel and patients, especially on axillary, inguinal, and perineal areas (165). Prompt intervention with antimicrobial therapy is recommended in cancer patients with septic emboli or catheter-associated and disseminated infections caused by C. jeikeium (77, 164).

C. jeikeium infections may also occur in children, usually associated with immunosuppression, a medical device, or trauma. Examples include meningitis associated with a ventricular peritoneal shunt, bloodstream infection, endocarditis, and localized skin abscess at a puncture site (166).
C. jeikeium strains may contaminate street-vended foods and vendors (167), as well as companion animals (168).
Colonies ofC. jeikeium on agar media are tiny, low, and grayish white and require at least 48 h of incubation for growth (63). The organism is lipophilic and grows only under aerobic conditions.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii
sect2.para: C. kroppenstedtii has been isolated from breast abscesses and cases of granulomatous mastitis among women of reproductive age, among others (169, 170). C. kroppenstedtii was also found in blood products collected from healthy donors and persons aged over 50 years with periodontitis, which is associated with transient bacteremia (171).

C. kroppenstedtii strains may be MDR. Colonies on agar media are nonhemolytic, grayish, translucent, slightly dry, and less than 0.5 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation at 37°C. C. kroppenstedtii lacks the typical mycolic acids of the cell envelope (63, 169).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium kutscheri
sect2.para: A small number of cases of infections withC. kutscheri have been reported, including bacteremia in hospitalized patients and zoonotic infection in an infant due to a rat bite (172, 173).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium lipophiloflavum
sect2.para: C. lipophiloflavum was initially isolated from vaginal discharge from a patient with bacterial vaginosis (174). Later, studies provided evidence that C. lipophiloflavum is part of the microbiota of the female reproductive tract (155).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium lowii
sect2.para: C. lowii strains have been recovered from the surface of the eye, although it has only rarely been implicated in cases of eye infection (175, 176). Colonies exhibit slow growth (<1 mm after 72 h) on Columbia base blood agar media in 5% CO2 at 37°C. C. lowii strains may also grow as convex, smooth, opaque, gray-white or light beige and nonhemolytic colonies on 5% sheep blood agar with or without 6% NaCl; they grow equally well in air and 5% CO2, and at 37°C and 42°C. C. lowii may also grow under strictly anaerobic conditions (63, 175).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium macginleyi
sect2.para: C. macginleyi has been mainly associated with human ocular infections (163, 177), but has also been reported as a pathogen of non-ocular diseases in hospitalized patients with comorbidities, including ventilator-associated pneumonia, surgical site infections, bacteremia, sepsis, endocarditis, and infection of prosthetic devices or heart valves (178, 179).

Colonies grow aerobically at 37°C on Trypticase soy agar supplemented with 5% sheep blood and on the same medium with the addition of 1% Tween 80. Very small (less than 1 mm in diameter) and nonhemolytic colonies appear after 48 h on SBA, but on 1% Tween 80-supplemented SBA, reddish-beige colonies are large (2 to 4 mm in diameter) and Tween esterase activity is noted.C. macginleyi strains also grow in brain heart infusion broth supplemented with 0.01 to 1% Tween 80 after 24 h at 37°C.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium massiliense
sect2.para: C. massiliense was isolated from synovial fluid collected from an elderly man who had previously undergone arthroplasty of the hip. Colonies are circular, grayish, glistening, and 0.5 to 1 mm in diameter when grown aerobically on SBA for 48 h. The temperature range for growth is 30 to 44°C (optimum, 37°C) (180).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium mastitidis
sect2.para: C. mastitidis may be part of the microbiota of the ocular surface. Ocular surface infections were reported in human patients, including cases of infections in patients who had ocular surgeries or who presented with conjunctivitis (177). C. mastitidis may be isolated from milk of sheep with subclinical mastitis (181).
Colonies grown on blood agar are nonhemolytic, rough, whitish, low, convex, and small (less than 1 mm in diameter) after 3 days of incubation at 37°C (181).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium matruchotii
sect2.para: C. matruchotii is most frequently isolated from chronic periapical periodontitis, which may lead to systemic infections (182). Cases of inpatients with bacteremia due to C. matruchotii have been reported. Interestingly, C. matruchotii was relatively more abundant in a group of caries-free than of caries-active children (182).
C. matruchotii exhibits Gram-positive whip-handle filamentous forms (Fig. 1f). Microcolonies appear flat, filamentous, and spider-like, but macrocolonies have a variable appearance.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium minutissimum
sect2.para: C. minutissimum is part of the human skin microbiome that is also linked to erythrasma, a superficial skin infection of intertriginous areas that typically presents as red-brown macules that coalesce into larger patches. Although more common in tropical regions, it may be seen in temperate areas, usually in elderly obese or diabetic patients (183). A recent investigation found a worldwide prevalence of erythrasma in the general population that varied from 4 to 15%, with a high incidence in men actively involved in sports (184).

C. minutissimum has also been associated with a variety of infections, including in hospitalized patients, cancer adults with solid tumors, vascular catheters, peritoneal dialysis catheters, prosthetic devices, and following surgical procedures (79, 98). C. minutissimum strains isolated from catheter tips, sputum, tracheostomy secretions, and surgical wounds from patients with health care-related infections were found to be MDR and to form biofilms (87).

Colonies are whitish-grayish, shiny, moist, and convex with entire edges and are about 1 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 24 h at 35 to 37°C. Most of the colonies are creamy, but some may also have a sticky consistency (70).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium mucifaciens
sect2.para: C. mucifaciens has been isolated from patients with bacteremia, pneumonia, endocarditis, infected peritoneal fluid, joint fluid, abscesses, and wounds (105, 173, 185). C. mucifaciens was also isolated from nasal polyps, nasal discharge of patients with chronic sinusitis, otitis media (186), and infected corneal ulcer (187). Bacteremia due to C. mucifaciens was observed to have the risk of developing emboli, as demonstrated by a case of septic cerebral embolus in a diabetic patient (188).

Colonies are slightly to overtly yellow and typically slightly to very mucoid, presenting 1 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation (Fig. 2c). They become less mucoid after extended (96 h) incubation.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium mycetoides
sect2.para: C. mycetoides strains were first identified in 1942 as causative agents of human tropical ulcers in the African desert region. Subsequently, five other cases of tropical ulcers due to C. mycetoides were found in different parts of the world: Central America, Spain, Portugal, Italy, and the Far East (189, 190).

The first isolation ofC. mycetoides from human urine was recently reported, and an initial study on its virulence properties was also performed. C. mycetoides was isolated from urine samples of a Brazilian patient following kidney transplantation and treatment with cyclosporine. This uropathogen was MDR. C. mycetoides is a potential pathogen for urinary tract infections in humans due to the ability to adhere and survive in kidney epithelial cells (Vero cell line) and to form biofilm on surfaces of catheters. The pathogenic potential of C. mycetoides was confirmed when tested against Caenorhabditis elegans nematode (65).
Colonies are nonhemolytic, yellow, shiny, circular, convex with entire margins, with 1 mm diameter when grown on SBA or nutrient agar after 2 to 3 days of incubation (65).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium oculi
sect2.para: C. oculi has been recovered from eye infections in patients following ocular surgeries or with conjunctivitis in Japan and Europe. Colonies are slow growing (<1 mm after 72 h), convex, smooth, opaque gray-white or light beige, and nonhemolytic. Strains grow in nutrient broth with or without 6% NaCl, tryptic soy broth, or tryptic soy agar at 37°C and 42°C (175).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium otitidis
sect2.para: C. otitidis (formerly Turicella otitidis) may be part of the microbiota of outer ear canals in humans of all ages (58, 191). Cases of acute or chronic otitis media with effusion have been reported, mainly in children (135, 191). C. otitidis has been reported as agents of auricular abscess, mastoiditis, bacteremia and venous catheter infection (192), cervical abscess, and ocular infection (193).

Colonies are whitish, convex, and creamy with entire edges, with 1 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 48 h of incubation. Gram-positive rods are relatively long (Fig. 1b) (58, 192). C. otitidis pathogenic strains may be MDR (191).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium pilbarense
sect2.para: C. pilbarense was isolated from an ankle aspirate of a male patient suffering from gout (194). Colonies are creamy, circular, and nonhemolytic, 0.5 to 2.0 mm in diameter, when grown on SBA after incubation for 24 h at 37°C. C. pilbarense strains may express MDR profiles (3).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium propinquum
sect2.para: C. propinquum is found in the microbiota of the nasopharynx and oropharynx in humans of all ages (121, 195). C. propinquum strains may be MDR (3, 196) and have been described as causative agents of community-acquired and health care-related infections (98, 196–198), including endocarditis, ocular infections (176, 199, 200), and upper urinary tract infections in cancer patients (79).
Colonies are whitish and dryish with entire edges and 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation, as well as nonhemolytic on 5% SBA media.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium pseudodiphtheriticum
sect2.para: C. pseudodiphtheriticum is found in the microbiota of the nasopharynx, oropharynx, mucous membranes, and skin (121, 163) and has been increasingly reported as an etiologic agent of community-acquired and health care-related infections in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients, including cancer patients (126). A health care-related outbreak of pulmonary infections caused by C. pseudodiphtheriticum in children with cystic fibrosis was also reported (201).

C. pseudodiphtheriticum strains have been mostly associated with lower respiratory tract infections (79, 202) and are also responsible for pneumonia in mechanically ventilated patients admitted to intensive care units (203), including patients with COVID-19 (204). C. pseudodiphtheriticum has also been isolated from patients with exudative pharyngitis (205). C. pseudodiphtheriticum clinical isolates may be MDR (63, 79).

C. pseudodiphtheriticum has been considered a contaminant of bacterial cultures or a harmless clinical isolate for decades, and the pathogen remains neglected and underestimated by some health professionals in different countries (205). Positive cultures in patients with signs and symptoms consistent with infection due to C. pseudodiphtheriticum should not be neglected. Moreover, MALDI-TOF MS systems may be unable to separate C. propinquum from C. pseudodiphtheriticum. These species are >99% identical by 16S rRNA gene sequencing, but they can be distinguished by rpoB analysis (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium pyruviciproducens
sect2.para: C. pyruviciproducens strains have been isolated from various infections in hospitalized patients (206). A case of mastitis in an immunocompetent 62-year-old woman was recently reported (125). C. pyruviciproducens strains may be MDR (63).
Colonies grown on Columbia SBA media after 24 to 48 h of incubation in an atmosphere containing 5% CO2 are small and translucent to grayish (63, 125, 206).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium renale
sect2.para: C. renale strains may be part of urinary microbiota (207) and cause human infections. The pathogen was isolated from catheter tips, sputa, tracheostomy secretions, wounds, and blood samples from patients with health care-related infections. C. renale strains may be MDR (87). Although the potential of C. renale human infections via zoonotic transmission is not characterized, C. renale strains are in the bovine microbiota and are pathogenic for cows and pigs (208).
Colonies are small and dewdrop-like after 24 h and become yellow and opaque after 48 h of incubation. They are nonhemolytic on blood agar.

sect2.title: Corynebacterium resistens
sect2.para: C. resistens has been isolated from blood samples, bronchial aspirates, and abscess specimens, mostly in hospitalized patients with underlying illness, including acute myelocytic leukemia, malignant lymphoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and cellulitis (209). C. resistens may be MDR, with some strains expressing resistance to nine classes of antimicrobial agents. Recent studies verified that daptomycin nonsusceptibility emerged among C. resistens. Nevertheless, C. resistens strains remain susceptible to vancomycin and linezolid (3).
Colonies are lipophilic, entire, grayish-whitish, and glistening and grow slowly under anaerobic conditions (63, 209).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium riegelii
sect2.para: C. riegelii mainly causes urinary tract infections in adult females, but pyelonephritis, urosepsis, and other types of infections may occur in both female and male patients, sometimes with fatal outcomes (102, 210, 211). C. riegelii strains express intense urease activity that may lead to elevated levels of ammonia in human blood. A case of severe acute encephalopathy and high levels of ammonia in blood secondary to urinary tract infection by C. riegelii in a pediatric (2-year-old) male patient was reported (212).
Colonies are whitish, glistening, and convex with entire margins and are up to 1.5 mm in diameter after 48 h of incubation. Colonies are nonhemolytic on SBA media (63, 70).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium sanguinis
sect2.para: C. sanguinis strains have mainly been isolated from blood cultures, but it has also been recovered from intravenous catheters, wounds, and bones, including from hospitalized patients (213, 214).

C. sanguinis strains grow slowly under aerobic conditions, but growth is enhanced with CO2. Bacterial colonies grown on chocolate agar medium are yellowish, dry, circular, smooth, and tiny (≤1.0 mm diameter) after 18 to 24 h of incubation at 37°C in 5% CO2. Most strains are tolerant to 7.5% NaCl and are nonhemolytic and lipophilic (213).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium simulans
sect2.para: C. simulans has been increasingly reported as a cause of various community-acquired and health care-related infections, including prosthetic joint and breast implant infections (132, 215). C. simulans was also characterized as a cause of urinary tract infections, bacteremia (216), and pyogenic spondylitis (217). C. simulans strains may be MDR (3). The recent recovery of C. simulans from sputum of a patient with pulmonary infection demonstrated its potential role in respiratory tract infections (198).

A recent study demonstrated thatC. simulans may be part of the ocular surface microbiota, although it was not found as the etiologic agent of keratitis cases reported in patients after repeated ophthalmic antibiotic exposure (199).

C. simulans is the only Corynebacterium sp. that reduces both nitrate and nitrite. Colonies grow grayish white, glistening, and 1 to 2 mm in diameter on blood agar after 48 h of incubation at 37°C (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium singulare
sect2.para: C. singulare has been isolated from blood samples and semen specimens of human patients (218, 219). Colonies grow aerobically at 37°C on Trypticase soy agar or agar supplemented with 5% SBA. They are nonhemolytic, grayish, circular (1 to 2 mm), and slightly convex with entire margins and smooth after 24 h of incubation at 37°C (63, 219).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium sputi
sect2.para: C. sputi was originally isolated from sputum of a patient with pneumonia. Colonies are nonhemolytic, cream-yellow, circular, convex, dry, and approximately 0.2 to 2 mm in diameter on Columbia SBA media after 48 h of incubation at 37°C (63, 220).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium stationis
sect2.para: C. stationis, originally recovered from seawater, was isolated from an infant’s stool and blood cultures from two elderly patients, including one with chest infection (221). C. stationis strains were also isolated from diabetic patients presenting with foot ulcers with bone involvement (222).

Interestingly, allC. stationis strains express the ability to alkalinize citrate, an uncommon feature among medically relevant Corynebacterium spp. Colonies are nonhemolytic and initially gray-white but become yellowish with age, about 1 mm in diameter when grown on SBA media after incubation for 24 h. These organisms are facultatively anaerobic, but grow better under aerobic conditions, at 25°C, 35°C, and 42°C (63, 221).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium striatum
sect2.para: C. striatum, originally described as a member of the microbiota from the skin and nasal mucosa of healthy individuals, has been increasingly recognized as a harmful pathogen responsible for community-acquired and health care-related infections. It can be transmitted from person to person among patients and by caretakers in health care facilities. A recent reported study verified that C. striatum has been identified in human infections in hundreds of cases worldwide (2, 98, 223). C. striatum clinical isolates are often MDR, with some strains expressing resistance to nine classes of antimicrobial agents (223, 224). Resistance to antiseptics and disinfectants, such as glutaraldehyde, was also verified for planktonic and biofilm-associated forms of MDR and non-MDR C. striatum strains isolated from hospitalized patients (225).

C. striatum strains have been isolated from immunocompromised and immunocompetent infected patients, presenting signs and symptoms that can range from mild to severe or fatal outcome (2, 98, 223). C. striatum strains have been found increasingly associated with a wide range of human infections as illustrated in Table 2. Recently, cases of thrombophlebitis (226), endocarditis (119), and ocular infections (157) were reported. Cases of C. striatum infections were also verified in patients affected by cancer (solid tumors), end-stage renal disease, transplant, alcohol use, and SARS-CoV-2 infection, among others (79, 227). C. striatum strains have been increasingly related to varied types of infections among patients with indwelling medical devices and/or with damaged skin, and with prolonged exposure to broad-spectrum antimicrobial agents (2, 223). Health care-related infections due to C. striatum strains, mostly MDR, in mechanically ventilated patients and catheter-related bloodstream infections have been described (2, 98, 223). C. striatum infections were also found to be associated with usage of cardiac devices (228) and joint prostheses (229). Moreover, C. striatum strains may be also isolated from chronically impaired patients following invasive procedures using bronchoscopes, colonoscopes, laparoscopes, and nasofibroscopes (2, 223, 224).

Colonies are convex, circular, shiny, moist, and creamy with entire edges and 1 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation (Fig. 2d). C. striatum strains are CAMP reaction positive and DNase negative (98).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium suicordis
sect2.para: C. suicordis, first isolated from the heart of a pig with pericarditis (230), may be also found in the intestinal microbiota of humans. This organism, when found in margin-surrounding mucosa of patients following resection of colorectal cancer, was found to be significantly correlated with anastomotic healing (231). After 48 h of incubation at 37°C, colonies on sheep blood agar appear nonhemolytic, whitish, circular, smooth, and entire and are 1 to 2 mm in diameter. Isolates are facultatively anaerobic, CAMP negative, and nonlipophilic (230).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium sundsvallense
sect2.para: C. sundsvallense was isolated from blood cultures, vaginal samples from a patient suspected of endometritis or pyosalpingitis, and sinus drainage from an infected groin. Colonies are nonhemolytic, clear or slightly yellowish, with sticky consistency and adherent to Columbia agar medium with 10% horse blood at 37°C (63).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium thomssenii
sect2.para: C. thomssenii is a rare human pathogen, originally isolated repeatedly from a patient with pleural effusion (232). This species is fastidious and slow growing, resulting in colonies of <0.5 mm after 48 h, but it is not lipophilic. After 96 h, colonies are molar tooth-like and slightly adherent to agar (63, 70).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium timonense
sect2.para: C. timonense strains were isolated from blood cultures of an adult patient with endocarditis and from cerebrospinal fluid samples from an elderly and a 16-year-old patient. Colonies are nonhemolytic, yellow, shiny, and circular, 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h or growth on SBA at 37°C; growth occurs in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions at 25 to 50°C (optimum growth at 37°C) (63, 180).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium tuberculostearicum
sect2.para: C. tuberculostearicum can be recovered from the nasopharynges of healthy adults (121). C. tuberculostearicum has been associated with community-acquired and health care-related infections, including granulomastitis, wound infections, abscesses, urinary tract infections, peritonitis, and osteomyelitis (151, 215, 233). The pathogen was also isolated from blood cultures, Hickman catheter site, bone biopsy specimens, synovial fluids, urethral swabs, wounds (genital ulcers), and cerebrospinal fluid (105). A case of infection in a cardiovascular implantable electronic device was also reported (228).
This species may also cause ocular infections (endophthalmitis, conjunctivitis, uveitis, and keratitis) (234). C. tuberculostearicum strains are usually MDR (3, 63, 233).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium tuscaniense
sect2.para: C. tuscaniense was isolated from blood cultures of an 85-year-old patient with endocarditis. Colonies are whitish, circular with entire edges, and nonhemolytic (63, 235, 236).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium urealyticum
sect2.para: C. urealyticum strains have being increasingly recognized as MDR pathogens that cause various health care-related and community-acquired infections, especially in patients with risk factors. It is associated with use of invasive medical devices, chronic debilitating diseases (urological disorders and cancer), older age, kidney transplantation, and recent urologic procedures (3, 79, 98, 237). C. urealyticum has been mainly identified as a cause of urinary tract infections. Bacteremia mainly occurs in patients with chronic urologic diseases (66, 79, 238, 239). Cases of sepsis, endocarditis, and encephalitis, among others, have been reported (237, 240). Cases of C. urealyticum infections are uncommon in children but do occur (241, 242). C. urealyticum may also cause acute or chronic urinary tract infections in cats and dogs (243).

Colonies are pinpoint, whitish, opaque, smooth, convex, circular, and nonhemolytic.C. urealyticum can be isolated after 48 h of incubation at 35 to 37°C, preferably in 10% CO2, mainly on SBA media (240).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium ureicelerivorans
sect2.para: C. ureicelerivorans was originally described based on features of an isolate from a blood culture from a patient with bacteremia (244). Cases of bacteremia and peritonitis due to C. ureicelerivorans in patients who have undergone invasive procedures and may be immunocompromised (colon neoplasia, leukemia, diabetes, among others) have also been reported (245). C. ureicelerivorans strains may express MDR profiles (3).

Colonies are whitish, creamy, circular with entire edges, dry, nonhemolytic, and very small (0.1 to 0.3 mm in diameter) on SBA medium after 48 h of incubation at 37 °C in aerobic atmosphere (63, 244, 245).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium urinipleomorphum
sect2.para: C. urinipleomorphum, first isolated from a urine sample of a pediatric patient (246), was subsequently recovered from the gallbladder of a patient with acute cholecystitis and from the urine sample of a 2-month-old child with gastroenteritis (247, 248).

C. urinipleomorphum grows on 5% SBA at 37°C under aerobic conditions. The species grows at temperatures ranging between 37°C and 45°C in anaerobic conditions (at an optimum temperature of 37°C). Growth occurs between pH 5.0 and 8.0 (optimum growth at pH 7.0) (248, 249).

sect2.title: Corynebacterium xerosis
sect2.para: C. xerosis is found in the microbiota of the nasopharynx, conjunctiva, and skin. C. xerosis causes various types of human infections, especially in immunocompromised hosts. Case reports of C. xerosis infections included blepharitis, a brain abscess, and sepsis in a pediatric patient with sickle cell disease (250). Subsequent investigations have questioned the reliability of identification of C. xerosis as the cause of infections due to difficulties in the routine identification procedures of Corynebacterium spp. in clinical laboratories. Separation of C. xerosis from C. amycolatum into the XSMA group (C. xerosis, C. striatum, C. minutissimum, and C. amycolatum) has compounded this difficulty. C. xerosis strains may also express MDR profiles. Colonies are dry, granular, and yellowish with irregular edges, 1 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation (3).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION OF OTHER NON-CORYNEBACTERIUM CORYNEFORMS IN MICROBIOLOGY LABORATORIES
■ Genus Brevibacterium
sect2.para: Brevibacterium spp. are an uncommon cause of bacteremia in immunocompromised patients (251). Brevibacterium spp. colonies range from yellow and buff-yellowish to whitish gray and are convex, mostly creamy, and 2 mm or greater in diameter after 24 h. B. mcbrellneri colonies, recovered from ear samples, have a more granular appearance and are drier than other brevibacteria. Gram staining demonstrates relatively short rods, which may develop into cocci when cultures are getting older (after 3 days). Brevibacterium spp. are catalase positive and oxidative; clinically relevant species are nonmotile and halotolerant (6.5% NaCl). B. casei is the most frequently recovered species in this genus, with others being rare pathogens.

sect2.title: ■ Genus Cellulomonas
sect2.para: C. hominis and C. denverensis have been recovered from a pilonidal cyst and cerebrospinal fluid and from patients with endocarditis and bacteremia. Colonies are first whitish, pale or bright yellow, but after 7 days, nearly all Cellulomonas strains form yellowish colonies. Colonies vary between 0.5 and 1.5 mm in diameter after 24 h, are convex and creamy, and have entire edges. Gram staining shows small, thin rods. These species are generally catalase positive, with variable motility, and are fermentative. Clinically relevant isolates are susceptible to tetracycline, rifampin, vancomycin, clarithromycin, clindamycin, imipenem, and minocycline (252).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Dermabacter
sect2.para: D. hominis is part of the human skin microbiome but has also been cited as causing bacteremia; wound, ocular, and skin infections; peritonitis linked to dialysis; abscesses; and osteomyelitis. Colonies are whitish, convex, of a creamy or sticky consistency, and 1 to 1.5 mm in diameter after 48 h (Fig. 2e). Coccobacillary or coccoidal forms are observed by Gram staining (Fig. 1c). Species are catalase positive, oxidase negative, nonmotile, and fermentative. D. jinjuensis and D. vaginalis are biochemically similar to D. hominis and all are also closely related by 16S rRNA gene sequencing. Reports suggest that MALDI-TOF MS systems can identify D. hominis (253). The antimicrobial susceptibilities of D. hominis strains suggested resistance to chloramphenicol, ciprofloxacin, clindamycin, erythromycin, gentamicin, and tetracycline and intermediate susceptibility to the penicillins but susceptibility to the cephalosporins, rifampin, teicoplanin, and vancomycin (254).

sect2.title: ■ Genera Brachybacterium and Helcobacillus
sect2.para: Brachybacterium species grow at 37°C and colonies are small, white-yellow, convex, and smooth. Species are catalase positive but oxidase negative. Strains are fermentative. Colonies of H. massiliensis are 1 mm in diameter, circular, white (apigmented), and shiny at 24 h on SBA. This agent is catalase positive, nonmotile, fermentative, and essentially aerobic. The type strain is susceptible to amoxicillin, vancomycin, rifampin, doxycycline, and gentamicin and intermediate to erythromycin (19).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Curtobacterium
sect2.para: By Gram staining, curtobacteria are small, irregular short rods with or without branching, which can become coccoidal in older cultures. Colonies are yellow- or yellow-orange pigmented. Catalase activity is positive, and motility is observed in most strains. Differentiation of curtobacteria from closely related genera may only be achieved using sequence-based methods. The MICs of vancomycin, macrolides, rifampin, penicillin, and cefotaxime are low (28, 255).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Leifsonia
sect2.para: L. aquatica colonies develop yellow pigment over 3 to 4 days, and Gram staining shows slender, irregular rods or filaments. Older forms may be coccoidal or cocci. Strains are catalase positive and may be oxidase positive (an atypical feature for coryneform bacteria). Motility, if observed, is achieved by means of evenly distributed flagella; strains are oxidizers (31). Sequencing of 16S rRNA can identify Leifsonia species, and L. aquatica has also been accurately identified by MALDI-TOF MS technology (32). Isolates may be resistant to vancomycin, and therefore antimicrobial susceptibility testing should be undertaken for clinically relevant isolates (32).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Microbacterium
sect2.para: The genusMicrobacterium accounts for the majority of yellow-pigmented coryneform bacteria isolated from clinical specimens. All shades of yellow pigment are observed, ranging from pale to bright yellow and orange. Most of the strains are catalase positive, but catalase-negative strains may be observed. Some microbacteria grow under anaerobic conditions but only weakly. Motility is variable. Definitive identification to the species level is possible using molecular methods; however, some species cannot be identified by 16S rRNA gene sequencing alone (61). MDR has been observed among Microbacterium spp., and so it is recommended that every clinically relevant strain be tested for antibiotic susceptibility. It is important to note that among 69 Canadian strains tested, 26% were resistant to vancomycin and 71% and 90% were nonsusceptible to meropenem and daptomycin, respectively, but all or most were susceptible to linezolid, rifampin, gentamicin, tetracycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (3), similar to results reported by Gneiding et al. (61).

sect1.title: Other Medically Relevant Genera of the Families Intrasporangiaceae (Janibacter) and Microbacteriaceae (Agromyces, Canibacter, Pseudoclavibacter, and Gulosibacter)
sect1.para: In general, strains of these species cannot be identified by biochemical methods such as those contained in commercial panels (e.g., VITEK 2 and API CORYNE). However, some may be identified by MALDI-TOF MS and most by 16S rRNA sequence analysis.

sect2.title: ■ Genus Arthrobacter and Arthrobacter-Like Genera
sect2.para: As described above, the genusArthrobacter has undergone considerable change taxonomically (40). Arthrobacter and Arthrobacter-like genera (as a group, called arthrobacteria here), including some extremophile species, appear to have soil and the environment as primary habitats. Arthrobacteria are usually yellowish or whitish-grayish, slightly glistening, creamy, sometimes a bit sticky, and 2 mm or greater in diameter after 24 h of incubation. Most arthrobacteria do not oxidize carbohydrates. As such, API CORYNE panel results will end with the numeric code 2004; that is, they will indicate that the organism is gelatinase and catalase positive but does not utilize sugars. Some, but not all, arthrobacters are motile. The identification of arthrobacters at the species level might be best achieved using molecular identification. Reports of accurate identification of medically relevant species by MALDI-TOF MS systems are scarce, although spectra for more than 55 species are included in the Bruker Biotyper system (Version H, 2021), with many represented by multiple entries. Antimicrobial susceptibility data are scant; Mages et al. reported that most (>95% strains) arthrobacters are susceptible to cefotaxime, doxycycline, gentamicin, linezolid, meropenem, penicillin, rifampin, and vancomycin, with some isolates being nonsusceptible to ciprofloxacin and erythromycin (256).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Auritidibacter
sect2.para: A. ignavus is a Gram-positive bacillus, which may or may not demonstrate a rod-coccus cycle over time. Colonies are cream-colored and smooth. Strains are minimally reactive biochemically, and motile only by the hanging-drop method. Antimicrobial susceptibility data are limited, but Yassin et al. found that the type strain was susceptible to ampicillin, cefazolin, clindamycin, oxacillin, penicillin, and vancomycin by disk diffusion (44).

sect2.title: ■ Genus Rothia
sect2.para: R. dentocariosa and R. aeria are Gram positive, with coccoidal, spherical (Fig. 1h), or rod-like to filamentous forms. Colonies of R. dentocariosa are typically whitish or rarely grayish-black (Fig. 2h), raised, and smooth or rough or have a spoke-wheel form (Fig. 2f), and are up to 2 mm in diameter after 48 h. Rothia strains can grow aerobically but may grow slightly better in a CO2-enriched atmosphere. Rothia strains have a variable catalase reaction and are nonmotile and fermentative. R. aeria colonies are creamy white and smooth when young but become dry, folded, and adherent to agar with age. MALDI-TOF MS systems appear to correctly identify R. dentocariosa (253). Antimicrobial susceptibility data from recent-era studies are limited. MICs of aminoglycosides for some R. dentocariosa strains have been found to be elevated, whereas penicillins usually show good in vitro activities against Rothia strains. Strains were susceptible to most drug classes tested, including vancomycin, in one study (257). It may be difficult to achieve acceptable growth when antimicrobial susceptibility testing is performed on Rothia strains which are overly sticky or grow poorly in air.

sect2.title: ■ Genera Cellulosimicrobium and Oerskovia
sect2.para: Cellulosimicrobium isolates are catalase positive and motile and grow at 35 and 45°C. In young cultures, “mycelia” produced will fragment into irregular, curved, and club-shaped rods. Colonies are yellowish and are 1 to 5 mm in diameter at 24 h and can pit the agar.

Oerskovia spp. colonies are pale to bright yellow, convex, and creamy and are approximately 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h. They are catalase positive and have variable motility. Members of O. turbata have unique properties compared with other genera of coryneform bacteria and Cellulosimicrobium, including extensive hypha-like structures (Fig. 2j) which can be observed on the surface or penetrating agar (but not aerially) and which break up into rod-like elements (258). Information regarding the use of MALDI-TOF MS systems for identification is scant. In recent reports, clinical isolates of Cellulosimicrobium have been identified, at least to the genus level, by MALDI-TOF MS and 16S rRNA sequencing (49), though C. cellulans and C. funkei are very close by 16S rRNA gene sequencing.

sect2.title: ■ Genera Arcanobacterium and Trueperella
sect2.para: The three medically relevant speciesA. haemolyticum, T. pyogenes, and T. bernardiae are all catalase negative and nonmotile and exhibit beta-hemolysis on SBA. All Trueperella species show a fermentative glucose metabolism. All grow and express hemolysis best in a CO2-enriched atmosphere. T. pyogenes may show rudimentary Gram-positive branching rods, while T. bernardiae shows short rods without branching (53). Trueperella spp. are not reactive in the CAMP test and A. haemolyticum strains present reverse CAMP reactions due to the expression of phospholipase D, a protein similar to that excreted by C. ulcerans and C pseudotuberculosis (85, 86).

The MICs of all β-lactams, rifampin, and tetracycline forA. haemolyticum and Trueperella spp. are very low, whereas aminoglycosides and quinolones may have reduced activities. Macrolides also exhibit excellent activities and are an alternative to β-lactam antibiotics for the treatment of infections. Treatment failures due to β-lactam antibiotics because of the inability of β-lactam antibiotics to act intracellularly have been reported.

sect1.title: Phylum Bacillota, Class Bacilli, Order Caryophanales, Family Bacillaceae

sect2.title: ■ Genus Exiguobacterium
sect2.para: Exiguobacterium spp. are alkaliphilic, halotolerant, aerobic, and motile. Colonies are smooth, golden-yellow to orange, and up to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h of incubation. Exiguobacteria present as relatively short Gram-positive rods or coccoidal forms in young cultures and may have long distorted rods when older. Identification should be confirmed using molecular methods.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Molecular typing methods provide essential information for analysis and interpretation of epidemiological features of microorganisms, including dissemination and transmission of human, animal, and zoonotic pathogens (64, 80, 82, 259–261). During the past decade, multilocus sequence typing (MLST) assays and whole-genome sequencing (WGS) became essential tools for molecular epidemiology of infectious diseases studies.

MLST analyses ofC. diphtheriae invasive strains (mostly from patients with endocarditis) verified that these DT-producing and non-DT-producing clinical isolates were found to be present in different clonal groups. Moreover, C. diphtheriae strains causing invasive infections may be also found in clonal complexes related to noninvasive diseases (261). The main disadvantage of the C. diphtheriae MLST scheme is the inability to detect variants with a tox gene coding for DT production (63, 64, 260, 261).

The BIGSdb-Pasteur database (https://bigsdb.pasteur.fr/) allows the analysis of DT-producing and non-DT-producing C. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, C. rouxii, and C. belfantii. Several investigations of C. diphtheriae epidemiology demonstrated that different genotypes are found in specific geographic regions or within diphtheria outbreaks (82, 262–265).

In recent years, WGS has become the gold standard of high-resolution typing methods, allowing the understanding of the molecular epidemiology, global transmission, and carriage of pathogens (259, 266). Highly discriminatory methodologies such as WGS for use in epidemiological studies are crucial in our understanding of molecular epidemiology, global transmission, and carriage of coryneform bacteria, including DT-producing and non-DT-producing Corynebacterium pathogens (64).

Pangenomic analyses provided insights into the diversity of pathogenicC. diphtheriae strains from cases of classical diphtheria, endocarditis, and pneumonia. Variation in the distributed genome is a common strategy of C. diphtheriae to establish differences in host-pathogen interactions, and this contributes to selective advantages for strain-specific niche adaptations, as also observed in varied investigations comprising analyses of the expression of multifactorial virulence mechanisms (64, 71, 259, 267, 268).

Genome sequencing studies have also examined the antimicrobial resistance genes ofC. striatum strains. Analysis of publicly available genomic data of MDR C. striatum strains highlighted that the resistome of this pathogen is dynamic, comprising chromosomal and other determinants mainly associated with mobile genomic elements such as plasmids and transposons (223, 224).

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Detection of antibodies directed against DT is the only established serologic test for coryneform bacteria. Toxin neutralization assays using Vero cell culture systems have been largely replaced by enzyme immunoassays, which are less expensive and faster and which can be automated. The correlation between enzyme immunoassays and toxin-neutralization results is fairly good, but less precise below 0.1 IU/ml. Antibody levels of ≥0.1 IU/ml of serum are thought to indicate long-term protection, whereas levels of <0.01 IU/ml indicate susceptibility. Levels of 0.01 to 0.1 IU/ml indicate partial protection from infection (73).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Clinical microbiology laboratories should undertake susceptibility testing according to their local methods, such as microbroth or agar-dilution minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) assays, MIC test strips, or disk diffusion assays on Mueller-Hinton agar plates with 5% horse blood. Antimicrobial susceptibility assays should be done and interpreted according to either the European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) or Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines (75, 223).

Non-DT-producingCorynebacterium spp. characterized as human pathogens have exhibited increasing resistance to antimicrobial agents. In addition to DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. (n = 3), at least 29 pathogenic corynebacteria species may be MDR, as demonstrated in Table 2 (2, 223).

Antimicrobial agents are needed to kill DT-producingCorynebacterium spp., eliminate DT production, limit carriage that may persist even after clinical recovery, and prevent further transmission from asymptomatic carriers and colonization of close contacts. Penicillin and erythromycin have long been the drugs of choice for the eradication of diphtheria bacilli. However, the increasing problems of resistance to penicillin, oxacillin, erythromycin, and other drugs including rifampin, tetracycline, and clindamycin are examples of challenges confronting both industrialized and developing countries. Moreover, MDR C. diphtheriae and C. ulcerans strains in different countries have been described (259, 268, 269). C. diphtheriae strains presenting resistance to six antimicrobial classes were verified in different states from India (259). Therefore, antimicrobial susceptibility testing for potentially DT-producing Corynebacterium spp. became necessary, especially during diphtheria outbreaks and in countries of endemicity (73, 269).

Invasive infections due to antimicrobial-resistantC. diphtheriae and C. ulcerans should also be considered, since failures to eliminate infection in cases of endocarditis and pneumonia following hematogenous dissemination from skin ulcers have been reported (97, 270). There is a need for antimicrobial susceptibility testing of these pathogens where diphtheria is endemic (271).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: The guidelines stating when coryneform bacteria should be identified to the species level (see “Clinical Significance”) are also applicable for evaluating and interpreting culture results; i.e., whenever coryneform bacteria are identified to the species level, the results should be reported.

sect1.title: C. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, and Other Potentially DT-Producing Species
sect1.para: In various countries, cases of diphtheria require notification of local public health authorities. Microbiology laboratories may also be required to notify public health authorities of clinical isolates of allC. diphtheriae, C. ulcerans, and ideally the other potentially DT-producing species (73).

sect1.title: Corynebacterium Species (Not Diphtheria-Causing Species) and Coryneforms
sect1.para: Repeated isolation of a coryneform bacterium as a predominant strain or as one growing in pure culture, which has an etiological relationship to the patient’s disease, should be investigated. If the organism is recovered in blood cultures, the physician in charge should be notified immediately, and it should be emphasized, when reporting, that the clinical significance of the coryneform bacterium must be carefully considered. One positive blood culture out of two or three aerobically and anaerobically incubated pairs of blood cultures is rarely clinically significant (except in cases of treated endocarditis). Care must be taken in the interpretation of the results for patients for whom half or more of the blood specimens taken for culture become positive for coryneform bacteria, in particular when lipophilic corynebacteria are cultured, since not all blood samples taken from patients with endocarditis due to lipophilic corynebacteria may eventually become positive.

sect2.title: Family Bifidobactericeae, Genus Gardnerella
sect2.para: The genusGardnerella consists of 13 genomic species, four of which were described and validly published: Gardnerella vaginalis, Gardnerella leopoldii, Gardnerella piotii, and Gardnerella swidsinskii. This genus is not closely related to other genera described in this chapter (252). It has been assigned to the Bifidobacteriaceae because of its distant affiliation by phylogenetic analysis to the genus Bifidobacterium. Until 2019, G. vaginalis was the only member of the genus, and earlier studies did not distinguish between the currently accepted species.

Studies on the ultrastructure of the cell wall ofG. vaginalis have demonstrated that it has a cell wall similar to but much thinner than the cell walls of other Gram-positive bacteria (i.e., there is a smaller peptidoglycan layer). The G+C content of these species, 42 to 44%, is lower than that of every other genus described in this chapter. Gram stains show thin Gram-variable rods or coccobacilli (Fig. 1d). Catalase is not produced; cells are nonmotile and have a slow fermentative metabolism (273).

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: All four species ofGarnerella have been isolated from human vaginal samples (272). The optimal pH for the growth of G. vaginalis is between 6 and 7, i.e., at the elevated pH found in the vagina. The organism can also be recovered from the urethras of the male partners of women with bacterial vaginosis (BV).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: BV has been the subject of much study by metagenomics and other cutting-edge approaches in recent years. Good vaginal health is associated with colonization byLactobacillus spp. and other lactate-producing bacteria, which inhibit colonization by pathogenic bacteria, and is linked to minimal diversity of microbiota. In contrast, BV was associated with at least four factors prior to the description of Gardnerella spp. other than G. vaginalis: (i) vaginal colonization by G. vaginalis and a diverse community of anaerobes; (ii) abundant G. vaginalis colonization is linked to disruption of the epithelial integrity of the vaginal mucosa; (iii) the presence of G. vaginalis is linked to decreased ability for the vaginal mucosa to heal; and (iv) G. vaginalis produces biomaterials which prevent healing of the mucosa, in contrast to products exuded by Lactobacillus iners, which help to restore mucosal wounds; the mechanisms of how these bacterial products work are being studied (274). More recently, the presence and abundance of G. vaginalis, G. swidsinskii, and G. piotii has been found to be associated with BV as defined by Nugent category (275). Other species of bacteria that are associated with BV are discussed in chapter 55 of this Manual.

Rates of BV range from 4 to 58% of women globally; consequences of infection withG. vaginalis in women include preterm birth, postpartum endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, upper reproductive tract infections, and increased susceptibility to sexually transmitted infections, particularly HIV infection (274). Cases involving serious infections (septicemia and wound infections) in sites other than those associated with the genital tract or in obstetric and pediatric practice, including infections in men, are very rare but have been reported (276).

sect2.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect2.para: Vaginal and extravaginal specimens can be collected with bacteriology swabs. It is best to take one swab for direct examination and another swab for culture, if necessary, such as for epidemiologic studies. If culture media cannot be directly inoculated, then the swab should be placed in a transport medium (e.g., Amies), and culture should be done within 24 h. It is noteworthy thatG. vaginalis is susceptible to sodium polyanethol sulfonate (SPS), so an SPS-free medium (or an SPS medium supplemented with gelatin) should be used to achieve optimal recovery of G. vaginalis from blood culture systems whenever G. vaginalis is suspected.

sect2.title: Direct Examination, Isolation, and Identification
sect2.para: The gold standard for the diagnosis of BV is direct examination of vaginal secretions and not the culture ofG. vaginalis, since G. vaginalis can also be recovered from healthy women (277). A bedside test for BV is examination of the vaginal discharge to detect the typical “fishy” trimethylamine odor, which is enhanced after alkalinization with 10% KOH (but G. vaginalis is not responsible for the amine production). The typical smear of vaginal discharge from BV patients shows “clue cells” (bacteria covering epithelial cell margins) together with mixed microbiota consisting of Gram-negative anaerobes (predominantly Prevotella and Porphyromonas spp.) and Gram-variable (G. vaginalis) rods and coccobacilli, whereas lactobacilli are almost always absent. It is recommended that a standardized Gram staining interpretative scheme be used to improve the reproducibility of this method (255). Although not recommended for routine laboratory procedures, the isolation of G. vaginalis, and perhaps other Gardnerella spp., can support the diagnosis of BV. Swabs can be cultured on vaginalis agar and should be semiquantitatively streaked out with a loop. Incubation is at 35 to 37°C in a 5% CO2-enriched atmosphere or in a candle jar. Slight beta-hemolysis is observed on human or rabbit blood-containing media but not on SBA (on which G. vaginalis can also grow, exhibiting alpha-hemolysis). Plates may be checked for the growth of diffuse beta-hemolytic colonies <0.5 mm in diameter after 24 h, but very often, G. vaginalis is best observed after 48 h. Gram staining of the suspected colonies confirms the diagnosis of G. vaginalis. Growth characteristics for the other species of Gardnerella have been described based on limited numbers of isolates, but these have been shown to grow in 2 to 5 days on agar with lysed sheep blood with 5% CO2.

G. vaginalis strains are consistently α-glucosidase, starch hydrolysis, and proline aminopeptidase positive; ~90% of all G. vaginalis strains also hydrolyze hippurate. Both the API Strep and API CORYNE systems can correctly identify G. vaginalis. MALDI-TOF MS systems should identify this bacterium accurately (278). A variety of methods have been used to detect this agent directly in clinical material, including “home-brew” nucleic acid amplification, Affirm VPIII testing, and the DNA fluorescence in situ hybridization approach (279).

Identification of species other thanG. vaginalis is not routinely done due to the limited information about their clinical significance and lack of accessible methods of identification. MALDI-TOF MS can distinguish between the species (272); however, only G. vaginalis is included in the FDA-approved databases for the VITEK MS and the MALDI Biotyper. In practice, G. piotii and G. vaginalis cannot be easily distinguished from each other by MALDI-TOF, and the same is true for G. leopoldii and G. swidsinskii (280). The Biotyper RUO database contains several entries for G. vaginalis (G. piotii is not included), as well as for G. leopoldii/G. swidsinskii combined. The 16S rRNA gene sequences are 98.5% or more similar and cannot be used to differentiate the species; however, partial chaperonin 60 (cpn60) gene sequences can be used for this purpose (275).

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: Metronidazole is the drug of choice both for local therapy of BV and for systemic therapy of extravaginal infections caused by BV-associated organisms. Systemic infections due toG. vaginalis alone can be treated with ampicillin or amoxicillin, since β-lactamase-producing G. vaginalis strains have not been observed so far. Routine susceptibility testing for G. vaginalis is generally not recommended.
The authors are grateful for the important contributions of Kathryn A. Bernard, author of the preceding version of the chapter, to the field of bacteriology.
